That being said, Shogun 2 is the last properly polished historical game from CA.  Great in singleplayer and co-op, all three expansions (though ROTS is the weakest) are good on their own and there's a high ceiling for the amount of enjoyment you can squeeze out of this game.

Would definitely recommend, especially when put up against other Total War titles.  Absolutely annihilated all TW titles released within the past 10 years.

CA will fail if they try to make Shogun 3. maybe CA can make some kind of comeback in the next 10-15 years. Eh.

Pros:
•	Despite its age it is one of the best-looking Total War games
•	Some of the best art work in the entire series
•	Simple easy to use UI
•	Well balanced and useful technology tree
•	Last Total War game to allow players the freedom of having armies without generals and allowing for units to be moved independently from an army
•	Some of the best siege battle in the series
•	Battles can be won using low tier units if the player plays well – tactics matter and are not just based on having high quality units
•	Best implementation of firearms in the series
•	Fall of the Samurai expansion adds another time era, more tactical depth in battles and a larger campaign map for a reasonable price
•	Best implementation of trading resources and unique buildings that can provide significant bonuses to units making them a lot more dangerous
•	One of the few Total War games with meaningful diplomacy which can be affected by your Daimyo’s honour
•	Aggressive campaign AI
•	Realm divide provides a late game challenge to stop players from completely steam rolling the map unchallenged
•	Some of the most useful agents in the series
•	Avatar conquest allowed players to customise their own generals and armies for multiplayer battles

Cons:
•	Units frequently get stuck on walls in siege battles
•	Units can bug out during battles where only half of the unit responds to orders
•	Suffers from bad unit collisions where units blob up on each other
•	Main campaign map is a similar size to a single Medieval 2 Kingdoms campaign map
•	For some reason 12 years after release, they decided to change the mini map to a darker colour making it more difficult to view the mini map
•	After the 2020 update where they released a locked historical battle, my fps has been a lot less consistent during the campaign and in battles which has persisted on different PCs.
•	First Total War to implement the shameless Blood Pack DLC
•	Guard mode doesn't work!

This review is for fans of Total War games and fans of strategy games in general, since I assume if you're looking to buy a game from 2011 then you are one of the above.  

There's very few games I go back to 10 years after the fact, and Shogun 2 ended up being one of them. Now that I have played every clan in vanilla Shogun 2, and three playthroughs of Fall of the Samurai, I can confidently declare that this is one of the best Total Wars, if not the best (based on your personal preferences). Some notes on why:

1. The AI is aggressive. This is important because defensive battles, ambush battles, and defensive sieges ONLY happen if the AI attacks into you, and the Shogun 2 AI is both incredibly aggressive and opportunistic on the campaign map. This means early game is very challenging, even on Hard difficulty, necessitating the use of ambush and defensive battles to turn the tides.

2. Successfully defending against aggression is satisfying. 

3. The music is stellar. This is the final game worked on by the Jeff Van Dyck, the composer for Medieval II and Rome TW. His musical genius is evident and he has a very strong grasp on memorable harmonies. Rome II and Warhammer Total Wars have music that simply melts into the background and are not very memorable in comparison.

4. This is the last Total War to utilize 1 HP units. This means that a volley of arrows are guaranteed to kill at least one person. This makes the fights feel lethal and punchy. In later Total Wars, each individual man has multiple HP, meaning a volley of arrows first softens them up, and only become lethal once their HP is depleted. This makes certain low damage units feel anemic and weak because of the gradual way they deal damage. In Shogun 2, every unit, even the lowly Ashigaru, has a certain level of lethality to them.

5. The battles are fast and decisive. The Samurai era is unique in that nobody carried shields. This means that projectile weapons are extra lethal, and the game has to be balanced around that. So what do you do when arrows and musket balls are so damn powerful? They make all the units move very fast. There are no slow plodding units in this game. Everything is lightning fast. The cavalry in Shogun 2 move faster than nearly every cavalry unit in Warhammer TW. Some people like this. Some people dislike this. I LOVE this.

6. There is a challenging late game. Every strategy game under the sun suffers from the snowball effect. You grow to a level of power that eclipses the AI and then the game loses all challenge and you quit the campaign out of boredom. Shogun 2 avoids this with Realm Divide. After your nation grows a certain size (about 1/3 of Japan), everybody bands together to stop you at all costs. This means there's an actual late game that can be challenging on higher difficulties (and challenging to unprepared players on lower difficulties). This gives you epic underdog battles where you're outnumbered 3:1 even 150+ turns into the game, something that almost never happens in other Total War games.

7. The sieges just work. They are the best sieges in the series. The walls are easy to dock on. There's lots of strategy falling back to inner layers of multi-layered castles. You can attack castles from multiple sides, baiting and feinting until you find the perfect angle to enter. All units can climb walls so it avoids weird pathing problems (looking at you Empire TW), but there's a significant cost to climbing them. Guns can actually dock and shoot from walls properly to devastating effect (compared to Warhammer TW, which fails at this in all three entries).

8. The roster is small but deep. Many later Total Wars fall into the common trap of elite units doing everything a lower tier unit does, but better. So you just replace all your low tier units and never look at them again past Turn 50. Shogun 2 tries to avoid this as much as possible. Yari Ashigaru, the basic militia spear unit, still has a place in the late game because it can form phalanx-like spear walls. While the high tier Yari Samurai, also wielding spears, is an offensive unit meant to chase cavalry and tie down enemy bows because it has a speed boosting skill but not ability to form a defensive formation. The lowest tier gun unit, Matchlock Ashigaru, sports a large unit size of 200 men. And while the Matchlock Samurai has better aim and higher stats overall, it only sports 120 men, meaning there's less potential firepower than the lower tier unit. The Ashigaru units can also be recruited from any province, making them easy to replace if one were to die in battle. These kinds of trade offs are all over the place, which adds a ton of depth to the roster.

All in all, this game is a 10/10 masterpiece and you owe it to yourself to play it if you like strategy games.

Loved the game to bits - was my second ever TW game and by far my most played one until I got into the Warhammer games, and I kept coming back to this game every year or so to do at least one full campaign.
What really helped in this regard was the modding scene, I mostly just used QoL mods, extra maps, or minor vanilla-esque overhauls.

Unfortunately CA decided to give the game an update out of nowhere last year, to make it use their Total War launcher afaik. This unfortunately broke a lot of mods as a result - can't even use something like Strongholds of the Samurai without the game immediately crashing shortly after startup. And there's hardly anyone working on updating these mods cause the game is so damn old.
Like I said, I love the game, but I can't recommend it in its current state unless you're fine with playing it almost completely vanilla.

Man coming from Rome Total War 2 to playing this is such a let down. I didnt know Shogun 2 was made before Rome 2, there are so many missing features when playing this you can tell it was made in the early days on the genre. One feature I liked doing in Rome 2 was selecting a couple units and clicking and dragging with the mouse to move their position forward, cant do that here. You also have to unlock fire arrows and certain unit formations.

I was prepared to give all its faults a pass if the game was still enjoyable, however the straw that broke my whole body was the realm divide mechanic. I cant enjoy this game because of that.

Realm divide is the most dumbest mechanic ever devised. I hate it. It provides no replay value to this game. In fact, I will never play this game again. There is no diplomacy. Ever faction just declares war on you, no matter if they are a one province weakling with 2 units.

The AI cheats so hard in this game. The AI doesnt have fog of war, it knows where each of your ships are if they are alone even all the way on the other side of the map. They will make one ship and make a mad dash to the other side to kill that one trade ship or weak ship. How can they see? They are cheating, no fog of war. They dont play by the same rules as the palyer.

And because they can see everything, the AI will also get on ships and land armies behind you attacking undefended towns, they can see which ones are undefended.

AI will spam one million ships. This is absurd.

The AI also has unlimited gold and gold boosts and their units dont cost the same as the player. I conquered all of Japan except one province, I let them live. This one province, without a trade port, still managed to build a max stack army.

Because the AI has max gold, they will spam the spear samurai, I cant think of its name, but its better than the basic spear unit you can build form the start. Even two province clans will spam this unit.

AI will have max level agents on the map and will succeed in all actions against you, every time. How are they getting max agents so quickly? 

The AI will suicide 4-5 unit armies into your max stack all the time.

In the battle simulator, AI will suicide their horse units into your spears every time. Also, the AI will just find the nearest hill and run towards it, they will camp that hill until you come and get them. This is boring, every battle is the same. The AI in the later Total War games are better.

Do yourself a favor and play on easy.

This game takes every aspect of the wargame genre and boils them down to their most fundamental aspects. This means that there is very little variation in units beyond their moral-attack-defense statistics, but it also means that the battle outcomes are heavily dependent on your own tactical abilities. On the strategy side as well, you will learn the capabilities of your neighbors, so if you pay attention, no attack is a surprise.

Pros:
-Excellent wargame simulator
-Graphics have aged well
-Makes you feel like a Japanese commander

Unfortunately, all that said, the AI is terrible at tactics and always tries the same thing. If they are attacking, they rush and charge your archers. If they are defending, they sit there until you get too close. Then they rush. This is especially bad in naval combat, where you can easily wipe out entire fleets with about 5 ships.

Cons:
-AI does not understand tactics
-On large siege maps the bastions' path-finding is laggy, meaning units will take several seconds to go to and from bastions.
-AI sometimes tries to go after cities which do not make sense to target (e.g., across the map, or several cities deep into your territory.)

This is honestly my favourite of the Total War games. The map is perfect in size and the ability to focus on different aspects is dutifully balanced. This is also the best form of sieges in the series, with manageable and succinct castle designs that make it intense but not drawn out. It actually makes attacking a risk and defending against a massive army a ballsy and potentially heroic event. 
The religious aspect is a little scuffed, and the difficulty spike means that after a certain point during a campaign it becomes incredibly challenging and then a landslide in your favour.
It's still a gem though.

The gameplay of Shogun 2, both the traditional and the Fall of the Samurai, are timeless.  In my opinion it has the best feel on the battlefield of any total war game and has aged beautifully.  After playing every total war release since Shogun 2 I can confidently say that this one is the best one of the series. Hilariously, the community is being revived now that Warhammer 3 and Pharaoh have lost a lot of respect.  It brings me joy that other people are coming back to this game after over a decade since it's release and are still having tremendous fun with it.  This game comes from an age when Total War was living up to it's highest potential, and will live on to be one of the greatest strategy games of all time.

Still kinda new to the total war franchise but this game felt overly unbalanced. I've played three other total war games and I gotta say this one is exceptionally frustrating. It seemed like every other turn my territories would rebel despite taxes being as low as possible, having plenty of food and utilizing buildings that generate happiness... and this was only after a few hours into the start of a campaign. On top of that I found it difficult to progress in anyway due to the very intuitive, almost psychic AI opponents who always seemed maximize on my mistakes or setbacks. This was with one of the easy factions by the way. After the tenth rebellion in less than two hours I gave up. Any time I tried to expand, which is kinda the purpose of the game, I would lose everything I had worked for despite my best efforts to consolidate. At my peak I had multiple moderately sized armies and one very large army, all of which were needed for the near constant and simultaneous rebellions. Basically what I'm trying to get at is this game feels broken. There are better options out there, options that wont frustrate you and leave you feeling like you wasted your money.

I am a 76 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my Son, who is 28 now. My son found this game at my house, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 276 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his work buddies or just watching tutorial videos. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. Loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Fair warning, I am a student of Japanese history and combat, therefor some of my positive opinions will be biased. So lets start with the negatives. First, I appreciate what they were trying to do with multiplayer participation encouragement and help intrigue but failed for longevity of players and revenue generation. Efforts into building a more involving single player would have been a more exponential growth winning plan. The DLCs are 50/50. The individual clan mods and hero adds to the original game are a fantastic addition while Rise of the Samurai is a waste of time and money. Fall of the Samurai DLC Generals' and agents' management, attributes, and actions are severely unbalanced. Overall this DLC is glitchy as hell but is still fun and a good purchase; to reiterate not great but not bad, just good. Historical learning events in the logs in all versions are absent and random events are more geared towards keeping a player "in check" rather than coordinating with actual historical events. Hard and Legendary campaign difficulties allow the AI to use cheat codes while stringently restricting player abilities. Facing odds that are mathematically impossible according to in-game economics is a serious lack of developer creativity. I don't mind going against AI cheats in premade skirmishes, but it should not be a staple part of the base game to earn achievements and game progression. It is possible to win under such conditions and it will take a seriously devoted player to achieve such, but a fair warning, it feels like work and not what I would consider "fun" for a game. Multi-player is 50% of the game and multi-player these days is dead. In these respects, history shows (google it), that the Devs and Company competently failed in both fun intrigue and revenue generation. They would have been better off not throwing so much money into multiplayer experiments where it was neither asked for nor ready to receive such a supply of. 80% Single player focus and 20% multiplayer budget and focus would have had a much greater reception and growth potential. Now let's talk about the good values. This is by far my favorite Total War game to play in Normal mode. Politics and faction behaviors are extremely historically accurate and precise. Civil, research, Army movement vs map size, win conditions vs map size vs turn allotment, and town building management is the best that this franchise has ever accomplished in my opinion. Units and battle game-play is one of THE most balanced vs historically accurate possibility results that I have come across and would place it in the top 1% of all single player RTS games to date.  Overall = The best historically accurate, single player, battle balanced, and re-playable value within the Total War franchise. Multiplayer is obsolete. Graphics are old but still compare better to some up-to date RTS games. Game management, settings, and options are cordially clean with minimal to no glitches detected outside of DLCs. A top tier worthy turn-based strategy game for the price of purchase. My favorite Total War game ever created.

This is the Total War series at its absolute peak.
Many people love the base campaign and, while it is amazing, I would say that I actually enjoy the Fall of the Samurai campaign even just a little bit more. I would highly recommend picking up the base game and FotS while they are on sale so as to give CA as little of your money as possible while still being able to experience this masterpiece (or you could put on your eye patch and sail the high seas).
This game is the best Total War ever got and, quite frankly, the best it ever will get. The good news is that the game hit the sweet spot graphically and mechanically so you won't feel like you're forced to forgo the comforts of modern gaming (such as panning the camera with middle mouse button) just to be able to get into this game. Yes, certain aspects are a bit outdated, but the controls are generally quite comfortable even for those who are more experienced with the newer titles and the graphics have held up due to the artistic direction that they chose.
My advice is to watch some youtube videos of people playing the game to get a general idea for what is possible. That his how I learned and, once all the systems clicked for me, it became one of the most engaging and deep real time tactics games that I have ever played.

Shogun 2 is an absolute masterpiece that takes strategy gaming to new heights. As someone who has spent a staggering 2800 hours with the game, I can confidently say it's a captivating journey into the heart of Feudal Japan.

The attention to detail is remarkable, from the beautifully crafted landscapes to the intricacies of samurai warfare. Having traveled to Japan, I was pleasantly surprised by the game's ability to capture the essence and spirit of the country. The strategic depth of managing provinces, alliances, and armies adds a layer of complexity that kept me hooked for hours on end.

Being based in the Philippines, it's fascinating to explore a different cultural setting, and Shogun 2 does an excellent job of immersing players in the rich history of Japan. The game's visuals are stunning, and the soundtrack complements the atmosphere perfectly, enhancing the overall gaming experience.

Despite my penchant for playing PC games, Shogun 2's ability to blend history, strategy, and immersive gameplay kept me engaged throughout my extensive playtime. The strategic elements require thoughtful planning, and the real-time battles are nothing short of epic, making each campaign a unique and challenging experience.

With 2800 hours invested, Total War: Shogun 2 has proven itself to be a game that stands the test of time. As someone who appreciates concise information, I won't delve into unnecessary details, but suffice it to say, Total War: Shogun 2 is a must-play for strategy enthusiasts. It seamlessly combines historical accuracy with engaging gameplay, making it a standout title in the Total War series.

If you're a fan of strategic depth, historical settings, and immersive gameplay, don't miss out on Total War: Shogun 2. It's a gaming experience that's both intellectually satisfying and visually stunning.

While this is a classic - the last good Total War game - the version available today is inferior to the original in a few important ways. 

Primarily, the naval combat is buggy to the ninth degree, thanks to patches introduced by the developers almost ten years ago which were never fixed. Ships can no longer sink, rendering cannons useless; the navy AI sits in place until you fire at it (at which point it scatters its ships all over the map edge, forcing you to slowly tour the map border picking them off); and the whole navy aspect is just frustrating enough that most players seem to disband their ships and play a land-only campaign.

There are user mods available to improve this, but they often introduce extra bugs, such as the notorious audio bug that makes archers sound like cannons.

If the developers had treated this classic with the respect it deserves, I'd have no hesitation recommending it wholeheartedly. But they didn't. Another salutary lesson in bad decisions from Creative Assembly.

What remains of the game is however worth picking up on steam sale - the art and music take you straight back to feudal Japan, and the battles can be spectacular despite the dumb and predictable Total War AI that we all know and endure.

This game is a perfect example of a total war game done right. The game feels very polished weather that be the sleek graphics in battle, agent videos, or the neat menus and tabs on the campaign map,  everything comes together very nicely. Unlike most previous games in the series, the campaign ai is aggressive and can easily end your campaign prematurely if you make to many enemies or neglect diplomacy which is a welcome change.  

Diplomacy has been improved greatly with the campaign ai generally making sensible decisions( e.g. they will usually accept any terms when close to being destroyed, allies will often offer money to assist them in wars, or offer to assist you in wars in exchange for helping them in their own)Allies  are easily the most reliable in the series and will normally not back-stab you unless you are allied with a treacherous clan, have become weak and failed to maintain good relations, or triggered realm divide(more on this later) , and have even occasionally send troops to help you in battles which is a refreshing change. 

The co-op or versus campaigns(when no connection issues are present) are a complete blast, coordinating attacks with your friends and building your empires together is satisfying and a very enjoyable experience. While it is unrealistic that you will both have armies in every battle, it is possible to give friends in the campaign units under your control in both the campaign, and on the battlefield allowing participation in each others battles, regardless of faction and distance from one another.

Now that we have spoken about what is good about the game, I will now discuss the main problems, the battlefield ai is hit and miss. Sometimes the ai catches you by surprise  with clever use of flanking, or whittling you down with massed archers when it has missile superiority, on the flip side the ai is prone to getting careless with it's generals, or playing far to passively on defense allowing players to take the initiate. It's most noticeably bad in sieges, where it often deploys it's troops awkwardly allowing them to be dealt with easily( e.g. leaving it's archers completely undefended) and will climb the walls every time, even if a gate to the castle is wide open, causing their troops to take unnecessary casualties and morale loss. Unfortunately though bad ai is nothing new to the total war series and  may stay this way for quite some time, however if this concerns you you may opt to allow a random player to take control of the ai armies on the campaign map to offer a (usually)greater challenge.
 
A lot of people are unhappy about the lack of variety in the clans, while each one has it's own unique specialty, and often gets a more powerful and cheaper, variant of a certain unit type, they do all use the same units(dlcs add some unique units to each faction, as well as one or two factions with many different units) although personally this doesn't bother me to much as playing to the factions specialty allows each clan to play differently offering a unique play through each campaign. 

Finally one of the biggest issues in shogun 2 is realm divide, this mechanic happens late in the game when you take enough provinces. This causes the shogun to fear your power and declare you a enemy of the state, the result is diplomacy is thrown out the window, and inevitably all factions will declare war on you, including your allies. This mechanic is not implemented well and can often feel unfair, although mods can change the way realm divide works allowing you to easily keep your allies and friends after realm divide allowing for a much more enjoyable experience.


Some people may feel intimidated by the setting of the game or the flaws that i have outlined, but i can't stress enough that this game is a easily among the top total war games in the series, and in my opinion is vastly superior to it's successor Rome 2. There are ways to deal with most of the games flaws which i have outlined above allowing you to take full advantage of the many great features CA nailed when making this game. 

Weather you are a total war fan that has not purchased shogun 2, or someone who is interested in the franchise or strategy games in general, i can't recommend this game enough.

TL:DR The game is polished and has some of the best diplomacy/battles in the series, multiplayer is fun and addictive while it does have some issues(siege ai/realm divide and a lack of variety) it's in my opinion well worth the price.

Avoid this one. The battles are actually quite good, but the campaign mechanics are atrocious and suck any fun out of the game.

- Realm divide is a terribly-implemented mechanic. If you get even moderately large and successful, everyone will turn on you and every single one of your allies [b]and[/b] vassals will eventually betray you. If you're familiar with Attila, this is like playing as one of the Roman Empires, except that all Shogun campaigns will end this way.
- The AI naval spam is absolutely unbearable in both the base game, and FOTS. Playing whack-a-mole with enemy fleets is incredibly tiresome. Ignoring them isn't an option as they'll either land armies next to your undefended cities, or bombard them (FOTS only).
- The AI agent spam is as bad as it's always been.
- Anti-player bias and awful diplomacy. This isn't news for any seasoned Total War player, but it's particularly bad in this game.

This is a game that dances on the razor's edge between a strategic masterpiece and a source of frustration, but not for the reasons you would expect. with its intricate game play, it promises to be an encapsulation of tactical depth, allowing players to immerse themselves into the art of Japanese warfare during the Sengoku period. However, there's a significant caveat to this experience that has nothing to do with the game's content itself. 

Despite owning a copy of the game, I've been caught in a quagmire that prevents me from actually playing it, effectively turning my purchase into nothing more than a digital ornament to admire in my library. This dilemma emanates not from my hardware or a lack of trying, but from an external source: Sega's bewildering restrictions and account management issues that act as a barrier hindering access even for legitimate owners. 

The game, in theory, boasts beautifully crafted landscapes, a compelling strategic layer, and robust combat mechanics that should position it as a jewel in the crown of strategy gaming. Players are expected to be challenged by its immersive campaigns, diverse clans, and the sheer thrill of real-time battles. Yet, this theoretical enjoyment is undercut sharply when you are persistently denied the simple right to play what you've paid for.

It's a paradox that the very systems meant to safeguard against piracy have turned against their customer base, creating a needless  struggle to unlock the very content one should readily enjoy. The resulting predicament is a clear case where DRM policies and stringent account verification fail the gamer.

The consequences have been a foreboding reminder that our digital libraries are now always our own. That crucial power - the easy of access to your digital games - remains firmly in the grip of the publisher. For those considering Total War Shogun 2 I might relay my experience as a caution against potential disappointment. You might purchase a game you can't play, a situation no gamer should ever find themselves in. 

Because of this I do not recommend Total War Shogun 2.  It is a situation emblematic of a larger conversation about consumer rights in the digital age. Players are often at the mercy of licensing agreements and DRM policies that can change without notice or reason. The message is clear: Buyer beware. What you "own" may not be yours to play, and that's a precedent we ought to challenge.

In my humble opinion, Shogun 2 is the greatest Total War ever made.

With it's streamlined design, aesthetically pleasing atmosphere, and well-paced battles, it is the perfect intro into Total War. Shogun 2 offers the most polished and gripping game-play I have ever seen out of this series. It doesn't tons of unit variety (as far as aesthetics go), or a gargantuan map with tons and tons of features, but it trades all that in, for a tight, fun experience that both newcomers and veterans to the series will enjoy.

Of all the Total War Franchise, I think Shogun 2 has the best overall feel. The battles are massive, the building/management stuff are pretty okay, the economics/finances are pretty good (it gets more and more fragile as you progress through a game, especially in high difficulties), and most importantly the DLCs bring a different but still fun flavour to the original game. Special mention to the FoTS DLC as it totally brought a clash between the traditional melee-bow focused army compositions against the firearm-cannon focused army compositions, depicted as the central theme in the Boshin War. I have only found the tech tree-research aspect of the game rather lackluster, especially with the very small bonuses each research component might bring even into the late-game tech-tree. FoTS also lack more "individualised/unique" units to the factions, especially those that could make or break a game (except for the very strong and fairly-early game Choshu unit, the Kihetai, or the Jozai's Yugiketai if not for its' max deployed unit cap).

tl;dr: a very worthwhile game, buy it if it's on a discount (especially bundled packages) or buy them full price since it's not that expensive nowadays (March 2019).

Total War Shogun 2 is perhaps the best of the Historical TW games.

A concise theme that would inspire other games like Britannia and Troy, Shogun is far and above the more solid title even today, graphically the game holds up better that Rome 2 in my opinion, and shaders/texture mods are always an option. Sound design from battle/menu music all the way to the whistle of the arrows coming down on their victims, you could close your eyes during a battle and be forgiven for thinking you were there yourself.

Unlike other titles like Empire or even  Rome 2, no major re-work mods are 'necessary' to make this game feel fresh and enjoyable, thought diplomacy is lacking in depth, something that *did get carried on into later titles.

Ultimately I do hope for a Shogun 3, it's been over 10 years, And I'm sure they could expand the setting to Korea and Northern China.

Side note, if anyone wants to Make an Empire 2 mod, with this game code? please?

Total War: Shogun 2 is an absolute blast in the small introduction I've had into the RTS genre. As a new member of Total War series, I can say that Shogun 2 has stood out to me more so than others in the series for a couple reasons immersive Setting, EPIC BATTLES, great mods, and SEXY SOUNDTRACK! 

             The game takes place in feudal Japan, which is such a bad ass and immersive setting considering the time period(for me maybe not so much for them), because of how warfare and honour were such a huge part of Japanese culture. The maps do the game well and are even pretty good looking for a 2011 game, ESPECIALLY with weather. The campaign map(turn based part of the game) was also surprisingly beautiful looking, even comparing it to Civ 5 I believe it holds up well, maybe even better in some cases.

               The battles in this game were so much fun, which is great because I believe that any total war game needs some grand battles to be a great game. How were these done in Shogun 2? Well all the fighting was matched combat mocap animations, which means all units interact with each other and aren't just mindlessly slashing through each other, it makes battles have a greater depth to them and feel more alive compared to " Cough "-- Total War: Warhammer  --" Cough cough ", but that's forgivable given how many races there are. Sieges are one hell of a time, from climbing the walls all the way to cannon balling the hell out of the walls and archers in the fort.

                Modding in this game just like any other total war game is unreal, the modders are what keep these games going YEARS after their release and I wish there were more ways to thank these people for their work and dedication to these games. Mods can completely change how the game is played, from better realism or even flipped to a more anime style unit set who can crush those who dare challenge them with no thought. I think without mods this game would be lacking a lot of things like unit variety and some smaller things, but thankfully modding is here. 

                 FINALLY the last bit of my rant, the soundtrack of the game, I think it offers a smaller variety of songs/tracks, but let me tell you what it does offer is phenomenal and does the game justice. The battle soundtrack is FUCKING awesome, I love watching my cavalry ram the enemy line in the ass or hunt the archers down, while still  hearing it play in the background like a sweet lullaby congratulating you for your great charge. I believe the music really helps a lot of other things in this game like immersion and the epic battles which might not be as great without it. 

Now this wouldn't be a fair review without the cons 
1.) It's old, no shit so some things are dated or aren't optimized well.
2.) Base game lacks diversity when it comes to units all factions are the same with different colours. (IM FINE WITH IT) 
3.) Some QoL things in the new games weren't invented yet so some task are painful and annoying, but still a blast to do.
4.) Sea battles were meh, but I feel that's more of a ship issue than game issue. 
5.) Performance CAN TANK and most likely will. Fire and dead bodies will make this game run worse than cyberpunk on launch!

                   In conclusion I think Shogun 2 is a fun game buy it now. What're you waiting for? DO IT!

Shogun 2 takes the title for most intuitive gameplay mechanics and innovation in game play features that it not only rivals with Rome Total War 1 however, it surpasses it by a large margin. All current generation total war games pay credence to Shogun 2 and over the years pound for pound Shogun 2 continues to foster a overwhelming acclaim for its brilliant game play and story driven narrative from the first Shogun to the present day reflection of the franchise as a whole. Shogun 2 stands alone as the best RTS of the Total War series and is regularly sees new content on social media as well as YouTube videos.  in one way or another you want to see what Shogun 2 is all about from first time purchases to long time fans reinstalling the game to unlock new memories with the game they enjoyed many moons ago.

Played this game when I was in college and it was just released back then. 10 years later, this game still hold up, fast pace battle instead of drag down like many other Total War installments that come later. With CA slowly out of touch on how a historical Total War should be and their cash cow Warhammer slowly run down, old game like Shogun 2 aged like a fine wine. Shogun 2 and Empire/Napoleon still the pinnacle of Total War series. Sadly with CA's direction right now, there will be no successor of those two games.

I've spent a thousand hours on total war games all the way from Rome through the latest games. Even though I always end up coming back to Rome 2; I may have found a superior Total War game. There are so many questionable mechanics across almost every Total War game, but Shogun 2 seems to have the best balance between variety, replay ability, graphics, battles, units, etc. etc. I'm genuinely surprised by how good this game is. Honestly, I'm shocked that they didn't continue with this model. If they fixed the few minor issues within the game, such as the AI spamming out endless 1-ship fleets to pester your home provinces, or the fact that agents always detach from your armies when you enter a city, this game would be amazing. The units are awesome. The battles feel historic. The battles operate similar to Rome 2, which is a massive plus. There's a lot of value in the 3 different campaigns. Honestly I wish we would've gotten another sequel in this series as opposed to the crappy new games they've churned out. There are no gimmicky magic or lore mechanics. Just fun nation building and battles.

This review is going to focus on Shogun 2 as its own game, not hop onto the CA hate bandwagon.

That said, it may be THE worst historical Total War title period. it's certainly the worst I've ever played. It cannot be understated how laughable the unit balance is, especially in multiplayer, and how little strategy actually factors into it.

Units die and rout off the field in literal seconds after entering melee combat, and melee combat is more akin to blobs of matter and anti-matter colliding than units actually fighting. Basically as soon as two units touch, one drops dead and the other keeps going. There is no time to lock down a unit in melee and try to get a flank off, because by the time your flanking force is in position the fight has already been over long before and one unit is probably gone from the field.

And when I say gone from the field, I mean OFF THE FIELD. There is no routing away from the fight and then reforming. Units shatter and flee the field entirely after just the first engagement in almost all cases, even if they've only lost 20-30 men in their 120 strong unit. Skaven in Warhammer are braver than the units in this game.

And speaking of Skaven, just like the ratmen and basically half of the other Warhammer factions, in Shogun 2, ranged spam is the name of the game. The lack of shields innately makes ranged spam overpowered, and there's functionally no counter because whatever you try to counter it with will, unsurprisingly, be shot to pieces before it can do so. The ranged doomstacks in Warhammer 2 wish they were as guaranteed to generate wins as those in Shogun 2 are. CA simply doubled down on this in Fall of the Samurai. The DLC basically turns this game into Empire Total War, set in Japan, and that's what the majority of battles are anyway because of how powerful ranged units are.

In multiplayer, the game is functionally pay to win. If you do not have access to the DLC units, you WILL lose. The units added by the DLC are objectively better than the base game units in every way. Unfortunately, multiplayer is also this game's main draw unlike most other Total Wars, as this is the only Total War game with an approximation of an entirely player made faction. This is the only part of this review that might come off as CA hate, but given this is the only game that has such a highly requested feature which has never made a return, making the DLC units so overpowered to entice people to buy them and stay relevant was almost certainly intentional.

I have well over a thousand hours in Total War games at this point, both on and off Steam and both historical and fantasy. Shogun 2 claims to be historical, but seems to be the original one shoving unnecessarily fantastical elements in, and as a result it dilutes itself into a disappointment.

There is barely any strategy to battles, you just rely on your units being innately better like in later titles and if your don't have the objectively better units, you have nothing, you can't use superior numbers, because the units die so easily it's like wheat being cut down such that a 60 man cavalry unit can face 200 yari cavalry AND the General's bodyguard all at once and WIN, simply from being from DLC.

There is nothing to be done to counter higher tier units, especially those locked behind DLC, because the counters to those units are in the DLC. And the campaign is simply not the main draw of this game. It's your typical historical Total War with silly diplomacy and stupid AI.

I tried to give this game a fair chance with how many hours I put in, both in campaign and in multiplayer, and both are just laughably disappointing because everything about it is so disappointing, the battles most of all.

If you're going to buy a Total War, buy literally any non-Saga title over this one. You'll get more enjoyment out of it.

The final hurrah from CA where they actually cared about their player base - before they started chasing the £££ with DLC add on's (Total Warhammer etc), new playerbases (Three Kingdoms) - back when they made great DLC (Fall of the Samurai), games were focused - and could be very hard (Yes, you can actually loose a battle, even the game here!),

Stylish, slick and endlessly moddable, Shogun 2 represents the pinnacle of the Total War franchise, and the start of the rot setting in at CA - its hard to believe we came from this - to discussion on forums being 'a privilege'. 

Sad to see what we've come from, and where we are going, remember Shogun 2 - remember when Total War was great.

Don't buy this game. You will think you are buying a "complete" copy with all the DLC, but after the fact, they quietly ripped the best DLC out of the collection, and called it its own game and to this day are selling the DLC as a full game at full price, over a decade after release. It's definitely the least worst of the total war games I have tried on and off Steam, but its definitely not worth buying at the absurd prices they are charging for the complete game with the DLC, $100 CAD provided you buy the whole game *in advance*. It's ridiculous.

The main thing the TW Warhammer series of games has over this game at this point is the decade of QoL improvements CA have implemented over the years. Going back and playing this game now does feel a little grating when you've gotten used to all of those minor QoL improvements. However, in terms of the quality of the field battles themselves I personally still think this is the best TW game in the entire franchise and the Warhammer trilogy of games will likely never be able to match it.

Pros:
+ Sequel to Shogun Total War
+ We're back to Japan!
+ Mods to make it easier
+ Christianity is now good!

Cons
- Realm Divide
- Crashes often (Mod issues)
- DLC Heroes and additional units costs money :(
- Otomo, Ikki, and Hattori costs money :(
- AI cheats with Metsuke and Monks/Missionaries

(This review is done on Very Hard difficulty, unless otherwise stated)

So far, I'm playing Shogun 2 with easy mode mods because I don't like my units to "rout because everyone is routing" or "Army Destroyed like Okehazama."

The game is fine, it's even better with mods, such as expanded Japan, +Korea, Additional Units, Realm Divide Fix Mods, GodTierUnits, and Noagent/ShipsAI mod. 

Those who played Shogun 1, Medieval Total Wars (Both 1 and 2) are for a nasty surprise. This game is hard. 
Especially when Realm Divide Kicks in.

Why so? Realm Divide is supposed to mimic the "Anti-Nobunaga Alliance" so I heard, and the game overdoes it. Here's how.

- The AI is given extra Unit power to take you down.
- The AI says "SCREW YOU" to any alliance and relations to you, even if you are very friendly to them from the start.
- You can't mimic the Oda-Tokugawa Alliance ingame, without using another player on a PvE game.

I use a Realm Divide mod to cap the relation penalty (It's more harsher in a harder difficulty tbh), and it makes a scenario where I can make "Tozama" and "Fudai" Daimyos.

The AI loves spamming their Rank 1 Metsukes or somehow Max Rank Metsukes on your agents and army. This is why I also use a no AI agents mod- Which is a lifesavor because the AI is LOVES to spam Metsukes and they often get lucky and either remove my other agents minding their own business, or turn my army to their side. The only thing the mod needs is to limit the AI from building Metsuke buildings all over Japan...

One bad thing about the game is Ship Combat. It's slow, and using Automatic Resolve is NOT GOOD. Fighting one ship with a fleet? Somehow that dinky Bow Kobaya can heavily damage your O Ataka Bune. Or even sunk it. I am not kidding. Sure, you can manually battle them, but against another player? Hope that player has the patience to battle in the sea. Oh and the AI LOVES to attack your shipping lanes, and unless you can redirect your shipping lanes to a closer effient port, expect money issues from the trade penalty and wasting money on a fleet to protect your trade lines AND your trade nodes. Yes, there are trade nodes. You need them to make certain buildings.

Speaking of Multiplayer, unlike Shogun 1, this game has PvP, and Co-op Campaigns (Not sure with the other Total War games). The only issue is if one player does not have the DLC for certain clans and units, it won't appear for the player who has it. Ex. You have the Hero Unit DLC, and the other player doesn't they won't appear in your Multiplayer Campaign.

Otherwise, even with these flaws, the game is ok, despite its difficulty.

Rating 7/10 - Or a Nobunaga out of ten.

Title: An Unmatched Epic of Strategic Warfare!

"Total War: Shogun 2" is a jewel in the crown of strategy games, blending unparalleled depth with a heart-rending atmosphere. The elegance of ancient Japan comes alive through the breathtaking graphics and meticulous recreation of historical elements. Each battle is a throbbing experience that tests both nerves and strategic prowess.

The balance between economy, diplomacy, and military expansion is masterfully executed. The challenges are demanding, yet fair, and the joy of a hard-fought victory is unsurpassed. The AI is intelligent, posing challenges to even seasoned strategists, while the various clans provide enough variety to keep the replay value high.

The epic music and authentic sound effects contribute to the immersion, making each campaign an unforgettable experience. The historical depth and lovingly designed campaign map transport players back to a time when honor and tactics decided the fate of nations.

Unlike its successors, such as "Total War: Rome 2" and "Total War: Attila", "Shogun 2" retains a clear and intuitive user interface that never overwhelms, but encourages the player to explore the complexity of the game. The successors tend to overcomplicate the core mechanics, losing the clear and focused approach of "Shogun 2".

While the newer titles in the series have their own charm and improvements, many fans miss the clear vision and polished execution of "Shogun 2". The successors often failed to maintain the fine balance between accessibility and depth that made "Shogun 2" a milestone in the "Total War" series.

"Total War: Shogun 2" is more than just a game; it's an ode to the art of warfare and an unforgettable dive into the fascinating history of Japan.

Whilst there's a lot to enjoy in Shogun 2,  it ultimately felt more chore-like than fun for me. I'm a big fan of Total War Rome, and that game had an excellent balance between all of it's elements. It's battle AI and landscapes definitely needed improvement though, and that's what Shogun 2 does best - when you actually get to battle the game is a lot of fun, and the Roshambo setup here is excellent. 

But the issue I had with Shogun2, is that the none-battle elements are just way too convoluted and tiresome now. Marriage, Spies, Metsuke, Religion, Navel confrontations etc. there's just too much stuff to get bogged down in other than the main reason I buy a game like this - the army battles. 

My ideal Total War game is Total War Rome's general play setup combined with the battle-play here, but as a stand alone game a large portion of the time I spent playing it was just boring and unsatisfying.

Don't buy this today- they force you to download their 20gig total war launcher that breaks shogun 2. Plus you have to fix the audio bugs on your own with a pack file manager. But thank god we got pharoah right??

Frenly reminder there will never be another good historical Total War game like this

Great game

This is one of the best TW games so far and I've played a lot of them!

Things I Like: 
- It's Japan. It's got sword-using Samurai. It's got cannons and rifles. Reminds me of The Last Samurai movie.
- Weather effects. 
- The controls for commanding troops are really useful
- You can eventually make your own faction, breaking off from the Shogunate, for example, and trying to take Japan by yourself without a team victory!
- Music and sound are great and on point. 
- It still has those crappy TW in-game videos that we all love, to show a change or progress in time. 
- The graphics are the best of the classic TW titles
- Mods are great, almost to an essential point
- Ships can actually aid ground battles if they're coastal by attacking the towns. 

Things I Don't Like: 
- What this company has become and resorted to. 
- The time limit to complete the main objective is not mandatory. It doesn't tell you this. 
- Achievements for multiplayer even though it's quite dead now. 
- It's beginning to age. Not as harshly as Rome 1 and Medievil 2 (the ones I grew up playing). I guess I just dislike ageing in general haha 

That's it. The game is great. If you're thinking classic Total War, get this one!

I've been playing Total War since I was in middle school when it came out in 2004 and I was 11 years old.  Back then, my favorite past-time was just seeing how big of an army of peasants I could beat with 1 unit of roman elites.  I spent countless hours messing around in battles, listening to heroic speeches (and cheating at the game because I was 11 and didn't quite get the campaign).

I was pumped beyond belief when I heard Rome II got announced and bought it immediately (in my Freshman year of college, boy how time flies) only to not be able to play it because of how broken it was on launch.  But it got fixed and countless more hours were spent and finally some campaigns beaten.

In that time I've also played Shogun 2, Empire, Medieval 2, 3k, Thrones, Warhammer I & 2 & 3 (Check my steam library, they're all there).  I even bought the Remastered version just because I love Total War.

And now, I will never, ever, ever do that again due to their ridiculous downfall.  Stop releasing bad games and silencing dissent.  Absolutely ridiculous this even needs to be said.

Total War: Shogun 2 is one of my favorite games of all time, I cannot recommend it enough.

The Good:
+The music, visuals, voice acting, and even flavor text all exude a wonderful samurai aesthetic.
+The gameplay is a great mix of turn-based provincial management and real-time battles.
+All the units counter each other and battles feel extremely rewarding.

The Bad:
-The different playable clans feel samey.
-The most unique clans are locked behind microtransactions.
-Naval battles leave a lot to be desired.

Bottom Line:
I cannot stress just how good this game is, I have spent so many evenings playing "just one more turn" and finally gotten spooked by the rising sun. If you like grand strategy games then get Total War: Shogun 2!

Total War: SHOGUN 2 - Where I Thought I'd Be a Master Strategist, But I'm Just an Expert at Making Really Angry Samurai (After 90 Hours of Bushido Blunders)

Rating: ★★★★☆

Total War: SHOGUN 2, the game where I set out to conquer feudal Japan with epic battles and cunning strategy, but ended up realizing I'm better at making samurai irrationally furious (after 90 hours of katana-clashing chaos).

Pros:

- I've mastered the art of bait and switch. Drawing the enemy into a forest ambush or luring them onto a bridge only to set it on fire feels like a mischievous game of tactics.
- The game's historical setting is like a deep dive into the world of samurai and shoguns. It's as if I've been transported back to ancient Japan, and I've probably watched enough Akira Kurosawa films to earn an honorary black belt.
- I've learned that diplomacy is for the weak. Who needs alliances when you can just build an army of ronin and declare war on everyone? I've made so many enemies; it's like a dating app gone horribly wrong.

Cons:

- My samurai deserve an award for most creatively frustrated death cries. Charging headfirst into enemy lines or getting skewered by a lone archer seems to be their favorite pastime.
- I've developed a fear of monks with flaming staffs. They're like one-man infernos, and they've torched my best warriors more times than I care to admit.
- The game's politics are like a soap opera on the battlefield. Betrayals, marriages, and epic feuds are as common as cherry blossoms in spring.

Total War: SHOGUN 2 is a game that invites you to become a master tactician but lets you revel in the chaos of samurai warfare. It's the kind of game where you'll start with dreams of forging an empire and end up laughing at the relentless misadventures of your clan.

To those contemplating a journey to feudal Japan: Embrace the strategy, accept that your samurai will make you facepalm, and remember that in Total War: SHOGUN 2, it's not about the perfect campaign; it's about the epic stories that unfold on the battlefield.

In conclusion, Total War: SHOGUN 2 is where I've realized that when life gives you samurai, castles, and betrayals, you lead, you clash, and you laugh at the chaos of feudal Japan.

The TES IV: Oblivion of Total War and all that that entails.
AKA the last good one before *Everything* went to shit.

(You can make the argument that Empire was the mask off moment, but you could also make an argument that the games after Rome 1 were already chipping away at what made Total War Total War. e.g. the cavalry charges in Medieval 2 were already worse than the ones in Rome 1.)

Or the last good/decent Total War game before CA decided to ditch it's old audience (that are the entire reason they have/had, depending on when the person started at CA, jobs and a company, then and now, to begin with; the lack of respect for their players, AND TOTAL WAR ITSELF, is palpable) in favor of a far less demanding/expectant and broader one.

Shogun 2's developers managed to salvage Shogun 2 into a half decent Total War game, despite the engine limitations and waning Total War design philosophy. Unfortunately, it seems Shogun 2 is the best CA could possibly ever do with the current Total War engine and design philosophy/target audience in mind.

P.S. Is it just a coincidence that when they fire/don't contract back their excellent composer, Jeff van Dyck, that their video games become shit?

I love this game. It's probably my favourite game of all time. It's also the only total war with a fleshed out multiplayer, and that multiplayer was probably my favourite part of the game. Which is the main reason why I am making this review negative. (I also have some things to say about single player if thats all you care about.)

CA recently put out an "update" in which they removed the ingame chat feature. This makes playing with randoms in custom lobbies so unfun, since you can't discuss rules or make map suggestions to the server host. Other aspects of the multiplayer have been broken for a long time too, like player statistics, leader boards, and clans. CA has completely killed the multiplayer community for no apparent reason which is kinda sad.

The recent "update" also broke a few things in single player too, like the preview map colours and the ingame encyclopedia. You wouldn't notice the map colours being broken if you've never played the game before, but the encyclopedia was an extremely helpful tool for learning the game and keeping track of things like unit stats and building chains. 

All in all I really want to say, "yes, buy this game!" because like I said at the start, I absolutely love it, but CA don't. If you buy this game, buy it with the knowledge that before you did it was a better game, and years down the line CA will probably continue to make it worse.

[h1]Shogun 2: Total War - When in doubt, recruit more ashigaru.[/h1]

[h2]Rating: ★★★★★[/h2]

Playing Shogun 2 is like orchestrating a grand samurai opera where the stage is feudal Japan, and the actors are armed to the teeth. It's a strategic masterpiece with a soundtrack of clashing katanas and war drums.

[h3]Pros:[/h3]

1. [b]Beautifully Crafted Setting:[/b] Feudal Japan comes to life in stunning detail. The cherry blossoms might distract you from the impending war, but the picturesque landscapes make each campaign a visual delight.

2. [b]Strategic Depth:[/b] The game's strategic depth is like a bowl of ramen - rich, satisfying, and requires careful consideration. The balance between military might, diplomacy, and economy is finely tuned.

3. [b]Engaging Battles:[/b] The battles are a spectacle of disciplined samurai clashes and cunning tactics. Watching your carefully crafted army decimate the enemy with a well-executed strategy is immensely satisfying.

4. [b]Diplomacy with a Katana:[/b] Diplomacy is not just about treaties; it's about forging alliances and betraying unsuspecting clans. The political maneuvering adds layers of complexity to the game.

5. [b]Cinematic Duels:[/b] The cinematic duels between generals are like intense tea ceremonies, only with deadly consequences. Each clash feels personal and adds a touch of drama to the overall narrative.

[h3]Cons:[/h3]

1. [b]Learning Curve:[/b] The learning curve is like mastering the art of the tea ceremony - it takes time and patience. New players might find themselves overwhelmed by the intricate mechanics.

2. [b]Occasional AI Oddities:[/b] The AI, while generally competent, can sometimes make questionable decisions. Witnessing an enemy army perform a questionable dance routine rather than a tactical maneuver is both amusing and frustrating.

3. [b]Siege Battles Can Drag:[/b] Siege battles, while epic in scale, can sometimes feel like waiting for your rice to cook. The slow pace might test the patience of even the most seasoned warlords.

4. [b]Limited Unit Variety:[/b] The unit variety, while fitting for the historical context, might feel a bit limiting compared to other titles in the Total War series.

5. [b]Occasional Pathfinding Issues:[/b] The pathfinding of units can be like leading a group of geese - they might not always take the most efficient route. It's a minor inconvenience in the grand scheme of warfare.

[h3]Conclusion:[/h3]

Shogun 2: Total War is a masterclass in strategy, blending historical accuracy with engaging gameplay. Whether you're orchestrating political alliances or leading your army into the heart of battle, the game offers a captivating experience in feudal Japan.

Is a clear downgrade of Medieval 2. Generals and family members are useless, both as a unit and as a commander. They die your army sure as hell won't give a damn about it, and your faction still works fine even after wiping out your family line. Naval battles are lack luster, most of the time the AI just sit here letting himself being shot and when they do fight back they are even easier to out maneuver than in land battles. Sieges are okay, but are so easy to go around that the player has no reason to fight one. The only upside is that the AI is actually dangerous on the attack. On land battle, the AI vary from decent to brain dead. Sometime they will trie to actually hit you where it hurts, some others tehy will send their cavalry into a Yari Wall and get slaughtered. Unit wise you can easily trash an army full samurai with nothing but peasants, making 90% of the roster pointless. The only real thing that Shogun 2 has really going for itself is diplomacy, where you can have friendly relationships and build meaning-full alliances. But other than that, go to medieval 2.

[h1] WARNING: After a May 2023 "performance update", the mod manager, custom maps, and multiplayer seem to be completely broken! DISAPPOINTING!

PREVIOUS REVIEW: Shogun II, as the sequel to the first ever Total War, is like a love-letter to the series. It takes everything players love and implements them almost perfectly. The campaign mechanics, battle mechanics, visual design, sound design, all of it. Shogun II offers three unique expansions set in Japan (only one is included in the base game), ranging from ancient spears and bows to modern rifles and ironclads. Multiplayer lobbies allow you to mix all three expansions together for a remarkably balanced experience, and, unlike any other Total War, allows you to easily port custom battle maps using a super intuitive map creator! Also includes an optional progression system for multiplayer that lets you rank up your general and units, which is really cool.

Few tips:

Play to the strength of your clan. Recruit cheaper and better Katana units as the Shimazu or No-Dachi units as the Date.
Samurai get special heavy armor the Ashigaru never gets and their arrows penetrate more easily. Ashigaru arrows have trouble piercing that armor.
Pay attention to garrison troops you automatically get when your provincial walls get attacked. They are completely expendable in all cases and eat up losses your vets would take in their stead. You build up the forts to get more troops, recruitment slots, replenishment, and archer towers that automatically fire on the enemy, and that eats up one more food for each upgrade. These don't get a bonus from your clan.
Try to have two cavalry units attack an isolated enemy that is NEVER EVER a Yari spear unit and have the one facing their back at full charge for heavy damage and immediately have them disengage to cut losses. That charge is used up and you are only going to lose troops by having them melee. When that enemy is chasing those horses, have your other cavalry charge for full damage in their back and repeat.
Places with trade routes you take over give you lots of money if you can build multiple trade ships for them. Ten is the most per trading spot, but each one gives lesser returns. I wouldn't really bother with the fancy ships and stick to the smalls and medium ships to absorb enemy navies.
Building up provinces with upgraded buildings that eat food are newbie traps. Food determines growth for each province, per turn, and you should only construct foodie buildings (upgraded) when you have Metsuke (build markets) who can settle and increase income. It is smart to have five of your richest provinces have all of the hungry buildings with five experienced Metsuke with the income growth skills to settle them for the rest of the game. It is a dumb mechanic, since those buildings make lots of money and eat your food, while your excess food provide the same growth when you get one or ten provinces. If you take a province that eats up more food than what you are storing, you will starve your clan.

The current development team of Creative Assembly keeps removing the features of modding, multiplayer lobbies, and chat support from Total War titles of the past development teams. Avatar Conquest was the greatest implementation of multiplayer in any Total War game to date, and one of the best in any RTS game. It was reliant on communication of the player-base, drop-in battles, and required no further investment from Creative Assembly. 

The mod manager is continuously broken with recent patches, with CA going so far as to update the older versions of the game to make it even harder to roll back the version of the game on Steam just to make it functional for replay value. Where are the patches for the mechanics of the game itself?

Creative Assembly has updated nearly every game released after Medieval 2, and caused huge issues for the mod managers and previously up-to-date mods in the process. Thankfully they didn't have good documentation or understanding of the Rome 1 and Medieval 2 engine and code, or else those would have been messed with too. 

CA still profits from these older titles, and they are not invested in dedicated servers. Shameful display!

This is a great strategy game. Almost everything in it is excellent: the music, animations, unit diversity, campaign map, art, pacing, controls etc. It's certainly one of the best Total War games out there to this date.

My only issue with it is it's Realm Divide mechanic. Basically, it's designed so that, once you reach a certain power status during your campaign, all other clans will unite to take you down. It tries to solve a classic problem that many strategy games have: boring and unchallenging mid-to-late games. Its a good idea, but its very poorly implemented. There is no transition period; all of your allies and even vassals will turn against you immediately unless their power level is ridiculously low after you taking 1 more province. There's no build-up to this moment; no warnings, no events, no nothing. It simply fills up a bar with your reputation to tell you how many provinces you can capture before triggering it. So it ends up forcing you to turtle once you're 1 province away from Realm Divide being triggered. But worst of all, once it triggers, you'll be facing endless waves of doomstacks coming at you from the other side of Japan. Seems cool, until you get tired and start save scumming to end it faster. Ultimately, it fails to fix the issue; from being bored of being unchallenged, your mid-to-late campaigns will be boring for being forcefully designed to be hard without much substance or nuances to it, taking away many things which were build during your playthrough (e.g. allies).

Overall, this is a very polished game. I would recommend this to anyone that likes games such as Civilization/Paradox Games or 4X. It has a great mix of strategy game design mechanics, and despite it's Realm Divide/mid-to-late campaigns not being satisfying, it's still a game worth trying.

The co-op mechanics appear to be non existent, there is no support for this feature which in my opinion is the main selling point to this game. Me and a friend started a campaign and make it about 50 turns in then the game refused to work and would not allow us to continue playing.

I wasn't entirely sure what to expect when I first booted up Shogun 2. My first exposure prior to playing was... Jesus, Angry Joe's old review from back in the day. I did know it was a strategy game and I love strategy games, along with this period in history. The Sengoku Jidai just captures my interest like no other period in history can. And Shogun 2, while obviously being far from historically accurate (looking at the Hattori), it captures the spirit and the feeling of the period to a T, matched only, arguably, by Nobunaga's Ambition. 

This is also Total War at its finest. Unit variety is a bit lacking to be sure, but with each advantage in how each clan plays, you'll not be left wanting for replay playthroughs. Just as an example, you'll certainly not approach your Oda playthrough the same way as you would approach the Otomo or Takeda. The DLC, while not perfect, is certainly far more fair compared to the likes of  Warhammer or 3Ks, which hurts me because I quite enjoy 3Ks. 

TLDR; if you can buy only one Total War game, make it this one. Combined with the DLC, Rise and Fall of the Samurai campaigns and the generous amount of mods such as Darthmod or Raidous, you'll be coming back for more each and every time. Glorious display.

The scope of the game can be limited. However, your choices of faction, and start difficulty present entertaining variation. The game is a fun way to blow through a few hours to relax. At the end you may learn something of the culture and people of the time.

If our daimyo is to become Shogun - military ruler of all Japan - we must defeat the current Shogunate, the Ashikaga clan, capturing and holding the capital of Kyoto for four seasons.  At this point the Emperor will declare our clan leader Shogun.  We can make a bid for the Shogunate at any time, although the current incumbent may pre-emptively attack us if we become too powerful.  War with the Shogun for either reason may result in other clans declaring war on our own in support of the status quo.

The Total War series peaked when Shogun 2 came out. All the new titles don't even compare. Sure, the scope and setting are rather small, there isn't much cultural variety, and there are some bugs here and there, but it really polished a lot of the mechanics and ideas from earlier titles. The Fall of the Samurai DLC has amazing naval and gunpowder battles, something that was slightly lacking in comparison to Empire and Napoleon (both of which do it very well, but FotS did it better). This is no in depth review, I just love this game, and I'm disappointed that I can't play it anymore due to the new patch. It also stinks that there wasn't another TW game with the mechanics Shogun 2 and earlier titles have. The OGs know what I'm talking about.

This has been my favourite game for 10 years at this point. Unfortunately since the recent updates, the game is broken. In May, multiplayer chat was removed and the mod manager was broken.  The latter was particularly bad, as not only could people no longer activate mods on launch, any mods active before the update would now be permanently active, meaning you could not turn them off either. You could avoid these by rolling back to the previous version, but as of the June update that is no longer possible. The community found a workaround that involved editing the game files to remove most of the update, which allowed us to play the game for a little longer. 
The supposed performances increases are in fact quite the opposite, my 3080 is struggling to go past 25 fps when it used to run double that on the same game same time last year.  
But the cherry on top has to be yesterday s update. CA added their own mod manager! Which doesnt work! And conflicts with the old one, so you cant run both at the same time meaning neither woks now. And you still cant uninstall mods. Which dont work because they are no longer compatible the current build. Given some of the changes to the game files, it looks like it could no longer be possible to edit both battle and campaign maps, meaning those mods could no longer be restored. Even if you want to play vanilla, the campaign now crashes on start. To top it all off, sound doesnt work past the intro cinematics. 
Given that every recent update  has been worse than the last I assume malicious intent, sabotaging older, better games to push new ones. Or spectacular incompetence due to awful hiring practices and working conditions at the company. Either way it s a great shame to see one of the greatest strategy games of all time be murdered in the darkness of automatic game updates.
Edit : Got the game to work, both modded and unmodded with some rudimentary game file edits. Performance still sucks thought. Worth playing, get it on sale, not worth giving full price to CA.

Easily one of the most polished total wars in the series.  One of the few historical titles that I've beaten almost every faction in the base game with.  The music is FIRE.  The battles are quick and visceral.  The campaign is rich and rewarding while also being charmingly simple.  Relive RAN and Kagemusha.  

Note that this is an older Total War, so the graphics aren't quite as good as some of the newer titles, but you get a good feel for the level of detail from the screenshots.  Personally I think it still holds up, especially with mods.  Also some of the battle controls are a little clunky, and there's some QoL features missing.

But If you like historical total wars, and you're into Samurai, welcome to the next 1000 hours of your life.  THE REIGN OF THE OLD SHOGUN, IS OVER

I've played other total war games before and somehow Shogun 2 manages to be both more complicated to play and LESS fun.

Unlike Medieval 2, the pre-battle banter scrip seems to be very limited, trying to max out a Play Tall strategy seems like a one way death trap to wide spread starvation, and for some reason they removed the ability to destroy walls (or just hid it very well) to undo the problem.

Basically its got gimmicks but its not as fun as Three Kingdoms and Three Kingdoms was not as fun Medieval Total War 2.

The content is nice, but its like some killjoy mandated that complicated resource balancing would be required for any sort of play style.

Hard Pass.

Even at a discount I'm disappointed, frustrated and confused as to how the Total War games manage to be more work and less fun each time they rehash their old classics.

One of the best entries in the Total War series Shogun 2 marked CA's return to their first, humble title in the flagship franchise that defined the grand strategy/rts hybrid genre.  Depending on whom you ask Shogun 2 is not only one of the best of the series, it's the last great entry in TW.  While that's not entirely fair as the games that followed have sometimes met with huge commercial success, many hardcore TW fans mark Shogun 2 as the pinnacle of the TW series as every subsequent title has been marred in one way or another by title specific problems.

This makes Shogun 2 one of the best entry points for players new to the TW franchise.  Shogun 2 has enough sophistication and depth to entertain for numerous campaign playthroughs, without being too overwhelming (relative to later titles that added more and more elements to gameplay that can impact play from turn 1).  The smaller but well balanced unit roster contributes significantly to this.  Shogun 2 may be the only TW game where turn 1 early game units can remain viable and useful all the way to endgame, but are not so overpowered to make late game and elite units irrelevant.

Shogun 2 is also one of the most beautiful titles in the TW series despite it's age.  While in some regards the varying visual styles of TW games are a subjective taste thing, most still acknowledge Shogun 2's beauty: the unit models and animations are fantastic even by today's standards; the environments pretty, alive and convincing while remaining functional (mostly, with only small scattered spots of terrain collision issues); and the effects (arrows, matchlock and cannon fire, fires, etc.) among the best if not the pinnacle of the series.

That said, the game is not without flaws.  While Rome 2 got all the attention for a badly rushed launch and numerous bugs (a fair number which still exist today despite the patching), Shogun 2 also had a fairly sizeable number of them that remain today.  Most  are fairly minor or can be avoided (if you're aware of them) but a few can be painful and naval combat in particular is prone to them.  Many players avoid naval combat altogether due to its messy and tedious nature.  While many of the land units are well balanced and fun to play with, the siege units are not and generally shouldn't be used or trained at all with rare exceptions.  Diplomacy, while not exactly buggy, can be difficult to figure out and generally is used minimally (it is total war after all, you can only play nice for so long).  Finally, there is a steep difficulty curve as you crank up the campaign difficulty, and some clans can be tricky to manage particularly in the early game.  The endgame Realm Divide mechanic can be a doozy to players the first few times around until you come to understand and anticipate it.

I also have to mention that the game is not optimized for multi-core CPUs (not surprising given its age), so some newer pcs may have difficulty running the game.  Mine runs it fine, but if your multi-core has particularly weak individual cores you may struggle to run it.

These downsides aside the game more than makes up for it in what it does well: some of the best balanced, vibrant and entertaining combat in all of TW.  Shogun 2 handles the core parts of TW gameplay better than just about any title and it does so in an attractive package.  I strongly recommend it to new players and TW vets alike.


No DLC is considered essential for this game (some would say the Blood pack, I never bothered as blood splatter and dismemberment aren't needed to enjoy the excellent animations in the stock game's visceral combat).  The Sengoku Jidai Unit pack is the closest to essential adding some flavor and fun unique units to the game, but doesn't ultimately change gameplay.  The 3 clan packs are all worth the expense if you want to play a different type of faction as they vary from the other clans (Ikko-Ikki > Otomo > Hattori for varied, unique gameplay).  Fall of the Samurai is an excellent stand-alone expansion, practically an entirely new game with new mechanics set several centuries later.  Rise of the Samurai is neither stand-alone nor all that interesting, but it is a revamped campaign in an earlier time period for those seeking something new and different.  The remaining dlcs are of much lesser value and can generally be ignored.
