Personally, I think Total War: SHOGUN 2 is the best game in Total War series. It is the most Japanese-style(designed) game I have ever played when considering its design & illustrations, and its in-game atmosphere.

At the end of the Ashikaga Shogunate, the turbulent era called Sengoku Jidai(the Warring States Period), players become a daimyo and fight to be a new Shogun who dominates Japan.

I love this game because each daimyo has its own characteristics. You can play a variety of games using various daimyos, from a daimyo specializing in a bow, spear, and katana to a daimyo specializing in shooting guns and cannons.

Also, depending on the player's ability and discretion, the outcome of a battle changes every time. Change the military power influence by using various weathers and terrains to your advantage. These are the biggest advantages of the Total War: SHOGUN 2. You can also come from behind to win like Oda Nobunaga at the  Battle of Okehazama!

Furthermore, the in-game graphic descriptions of Japanese-style castles, architecture, and natural environment are excellent, and the battle scene is so realistic, so it's fun to watch.

Total War: SHOGUN 2 is a game that even gamers who don't play Total War series should play at least once in their lives. It will be a great experience! I highly recommend this game.

※ I highly advise you to buy Blood Pack DLC. I can't even imagine a bloodless battle scene in this game!

Total War: Shogun 2 is definitely the most balanced Total War game to date next to the likes of Medieval 2 and Rome Total War. It's really hard to beat its simple and straightforward mechanics that lend to the games replayability after all these years. 
Highly recommend for anyone who hasn't tried it yet, also a great introduction into the series if you've never played a Total War game. (Although I would recommend Rome Total War or Medieval 2 as a first game over this one) 

PROS  

- Graphics that still hold up very nicely to this day. Beautiful colour palletes and overall map and unit designs as well as artwork

- Full scale battles can feel intense as they can be fast paced and require quick thinking and strategical movement

- Lots of factions to choose from that each have their own pros and cons as well as difficulties to change up the play style from Clan to Clan (unique units, starting positions, buffs and debuffs that are Clan specific)

- Naval battles which are a welcome addition 

- Lack of an extensive unit variety leads to more strategic thinking and army planning as instead of brute forcing overpowered units, you win through cunning and thought out plans especially against more difficult AI

- Co-op Head to Head campaign takes the game to a whole new level in terms of enjoyment and planning

- Fleshed out technology trees that greatly enhance your Clan anywhere from economy, social and political, and military buffs

- One of the best DLCs that has ever come out for any Total War game in the franchise that serves as its own standalone game


CONS

- As it is set in Feudal Japan and as I mentioned in the PROS section, there is a lack of unit variety even with the inclusion of Clan specific units that are unique. Easily mitigated by mods but for those who want a vanilla experience, you may find that unit progression is lacking. Also more fleshed out in its DLC but still suffers from somewhat lack of real unit variety.

- Although naval battles are a welcome addition, in the base game they can feel like a slog fest. Also naval battles are much more RNG based than a land battle as Naval moral is finicky and usually whoever has the larger fleet usually wins due to the inherent mechanics of Vanilla naval battles. The DLC naval battles are much more fleshed out but they still suffer from an emphasis on RNG

- Siege battles, which are a large component of the game can become very repetitive. The attacker is always left at a huge disadvantage (which makes complete sense) but steam rolling settlements that are even moderately defended is not easy and you can expect to take huge losses unless you are fighting every single battle which is time consuming. Even then you will suffer heavy causalities unless you force the defender to sally forth. Defending in a siege is generally extremely easy as missile units become overpowered due to the design and mechanics of siege defenses. It's easy to hold cities, it's a lot harder to capture them. 

- Whether or not this is a CON is for the reader to judge. Inherently it is so I included it in this section. Generals, which are the leaders of your army and provide buffs to your units and debuffs to the enemies are very easily killed. They do not have anything that makes them more powerful than a regular fielded unit. The only thing marking them as the general is their banner and their unique unit which is a Bodyguard unit. Personally I like the vulnerability in this aspect. It makes investing in a general feel more weighty and really forces you to micromanage which I believe is a fun aspect of the game. 

- Although a very straightforward game in nature, it can have a steep learning curve which can be intimidating. Personally I enjoy that aspect about Shogun 2


In conclusion, definitely one of my top 3 favourite Total Wars and a huge recommendation to anyone looking to purchase it.

One of my favorite Total War games. Fall of the Samurai makes it 10x better,

HOWEVER, CA the parent company of the Total War franchise decided to update the game again May 2023, after years of no communication (while there were still unfinished bugs). Now while this would be a welcome sign for any type of legacy game, it seems CA didnt see it that way. CA decided to remove the global chat from multiplayer due to "legal reasons"; Some may hate that idea, but in general it didnt affect even 20% of the current playerbase for the game. BUT CA, in its infinite wisdom, broke the games Mod Manager during this patch, and every patch since May 2023 hasnt fixed the issue and only made things worse (now all mods are now incompatible with the game version :) ). 

I will change my review once I have played the game and seen these problems resolved. Right now, sale or not, its a risky purchase under CA's direction. (This is a warning for their other titles too)

I do not care for the Shogun turns everyone against you mechanic. Beyond this issue, this is truly one of the last if not the last really great Total War games. The factions all feel unique even the units are individualized enough to feel like every play-through is something different and almost all factions can be played differently. The tech tree makes you either go economic and build up everything playing tall or going bushido and trying to maintain one doom stack of ever improving samurai as your enemies mount. The terrain of each battle matters greatly and even though the AI can get a bit head-long charging, it will do intelligent things like wait for its reinforcements, take the high-ground when getting attacked, and putting out a skirmish line of archers/muskets before engaging. Anytime this game is on sale I would purchase immediately and even full price is worth it if you have an interest in this era.

Be careful if you want to spend your money on this. On its own it is a fantastic game and one of the best Total War titles. However, despite its age, the company behind it is actively ruining it with updates to force players to migrate to their newer, more mediocre titles. Right now, they've not only removed ingame chat from multiplayer, but have butchered the mod support for the game - there are workarounds for that right now from the community, but considering CA's greed I wouldn't be surprised if they played whack a mole and kept neutering those solutions with additional updates. Worse still, I've seen posts online (though haven't personally experienced it) that some people now have issues with vanilla features after the update, including regular units and techs suddenly being inaccessible in vanilla. This isn't the first time CA has done this, so be ready for it to get a lot worse in the future if their mediocre new titles don't make money (which they won't). If you really want this game and don't want to wear an eyepatch to get it, be sure to only give this "wonderful" company pennies for it on sale and be certain that there is still a community-made workaround to enable mods that works at the time of your purchase. If there isn't such a workaround anymore, I wouldn't bother buying since half the fun of this game was the flexibility of the community content, and the greedy degenerate pricks at CA would rather be vampiric leeches and take that away than make actually good new games.

Truly the best Total War ever. Gameplaywise.

- There are historical characters here, however you will start the campaign playing as their fathers, and the real sengoku heroes will be born (spawn) later.

- Yes the campaign is missing some older features, but the most important things are there and the armies are still nicely manageable here. Only you cannot recruit generals directly. You either wait for some noble to come of age or you have to make one yourself by wining a tough battle. The battles are fast paced, yet realistic (appart from the wall climbing... I don't know what was CA thinking there...)- Every clash of two wapons of any type is nicely synched and animated, as well as every kill, but it does not slows the game down or messes up the ballance at all. The battle maps look nice, only sieges look boring. since the cities and castles are only walls, with no buildings, streets and such. The AI is much, much smarter than in Empire or Napoleon.

-  Naval battles are a mixed bag. When they work they are fun, there's an emphasis on boarding here unlike in previous games, but sometimes they are a pain to do. The AI is really stupid here. It won't do exactly what you want it to do and sometimes two of your ships will ram into each other and block their way for no reason. Luckily the enemy AI does it as well.

Amazing game, until realm divide

For the record, I have played total war games for over 5 years, own almost all of them and have beaten almost all of them (war hammer excepted) this was my last game to do, I played several campaigns on normal difficulty.

The game has excellent combat, diplomacy, factions, buildings and tech tree. However, due to most places only having one or two recruiting slots, and having most good units take 2 turns to train, it demands that the game is played in a very slow pace. 

However, the demand of 25 provinces in 125 turns makes one rush, this however, is not the worst, the worst is that while the game is finely crafted strategy up until realm divide, it is miserable afterward as every single faction attacks you relentlessly. This ends all trade and diplomatic strategy, and turns it into a constant slog fest where you are still required to take 8 or so provinces. And you will be attacked by doom stack after doom stack without any chance to rebuild or strategize.
Shogun 2 was a good game, until CA came back 10+ years later to brick the game and gut the multiplayer. Shameful display!

CA really outdid themselves. Truly. 

Their ability to completely bust their older titles is simply unmatched. Firstly, the move to remove all chat abilities from the game was a masterstroke of genius. A "minor technical update" indeed, it didn't affect my ability to play whatsoever. Who needs to be able to talk to one another in a multiplayer game? Finding buddies to play with and organizing groups in a lobby is overrated.

But it's recently been topped off by their new Mona Lisa: Silently removing the mod manager. Shogun 2 is such a masterpiece that downloading mods of which fixed broken sounds, performance stutters, AI mishaps, and compatibility with newer hardware is completely unnecessary. Awesome stuff! Oh, and I hope you were satisfied with the mods that were already downloaded because now you're stuck with them for the rest of your Shogun 2 career because there's no way to remove or configure them and Steam will automatically reinstall them as part of Steam Cloud.

CA's response to this? Ever so gracefully hidden away in the Steam comments of a thread pointing out the above defecation. They mention that an update will soon be on the way, but we already know what kind of "improvements" are included in those. And as such, I am correct in predicting they'll improve this classic even further!

For a short period of time, there was a workaround for those unsatisfied with the removal of mods or chatrooms (the audacity of these folks, boggling) that involved swapping the Steam beta build from the main build (CA's masterpiece, stripped to the nude core) and the pre-2022 linux build (brilliantly named to prevent non-curious Windows users from swapping over). This fixed new performance issues introduced in the main build and allowed the continuous use of the mod manager. Pretty handy stuff.

Remember that proposed patch that CA was going to give us? The one hidden in a thread on Steam somewhere? Well, it arrived. A question that may arise is "Did they fix the problem?" And that is a fair question, but CA entirely forgot to define what the "problem" was in the first place. The problem being that people used a workaround to get the mod manager and stability back into their game. And thus, they patched in a way to break the workaround builds. as well as the main build.

On top of this, the devs even saw fit to remove "Workshop Support" from the Steam store page right at a major Steam sale and after they "fixed" all the "problems" that made Shogun 2 great, and left it in a truly "realized" state.

All joking aside, CA's tomfoolery, trolling, and otherwise degenerate malicious updates to their older titles to discourage their use and to promote the new fecal matter that they keep spewing out is intolerable. Top unprofessional-ism from the U.K.'s largest video game developer was unexpected, but unsurprising. I would suggest steering clear of anything they release, as Shogun 2 isn't their only victim. Empire, Napoleon, and Rome 2 are also being hit by these insane deployments and the company itself either doesn't say anything about it and sneakily updates them or brazenly announces that they are doing it with some snarky Steam forum post and go "woe is me, buy my new stuff and all the DLCs" when they're called out on it. Absolute bullshit.

Updating my review, since ive played 400 more hours.
TWS2 is a masterpiece of a game, one of **THE BEST** CA ever made, in terms of atmosphere, the way battles go, mechanic, and thanks to modding community, there is none other strategy game as good as this one. Each battle feels important, and you can see each soldier fighting for their own life, fighting their battles, its not plain "AI#21992 swings sword at AI#02932 dealing 15 damage", each soldier is fighting in a hand-to-hand, one of them is going to emerge victorious, a fight between a freshmeat peasant and a battle-hardened samurai is determined by many factors like: fatigue of the warriors, their skill, their weapons, the weapons of their enemy, the terrain. All of this combined makes a very immersive and enjoyable game.
Now cons:
1. Undeveloped AI both in battles and on world map politics. In a battle it doesnt matter what size the bots army is, they WILL attack head-on, using the same basic strategy "archers in front, footmen behind at the ready", if the bot is defending it will immediately run to the nearest highground (as you should), make a "basic strategy" formation and just wait for you to come and attack.
2. Unit Controls. This ones the most annoying during 50/50 battles, because a single elite unit being confused as to how to get to the place i pointed at can be very crucial to your entire battle.
3. Multiplayer. My most painful problem with it is de-sync when you play for a long time, or black loading screen for either host or the player when loading into a battle, very annoying and we all know CA couldve done better, but they kinda dropped it.

But enough for bad things, the game is really good, it feels satisfying to play it even with these bugs and problems and undeveloped AI. TWS2 is not just good, its a great piece of art that still needs improvement, thankfully there are mods that make your gameplay experience better, but its not enough, unfortunately, we need an official bug fixing patch. 
My rating for the game is 8/10

Over 300 hours in this game, and it gets a thumbs down from me. Why? Keep reading...

Dozens of times I've stopped playing this game, returned wondering why I quit in the first place, only to get frustrated and quit again.

I never could quite put my finger on why I always ended up hating it and coming back. Now I've finally decided to put my frustration to text.


Shogun 2 is a beautiful-[b]looking[/b] game. It has nice graphics, with a UI and artstyle that nicely captures the game's theme of feudal Japan. The game is full of [b]promise[/b]; different playstyles, different strategies, massive tech trees with elaborate benefits and unique buildings, etc.

The early-game experience in Shogun 2 tends to be quite fun, however as one progresses through the campaign its flaws rapidly become apparent:

1. On the lower difficulties, the game is an absolute cakewalk. After capturing a handful of provinces your economy will start to boom and you'll finish even the Domination campaign (basically capturing all of Japan) with ashigaru armies, long before any of the more interesting technologies get unlocked.

One could artifically lengthen the campaign by simply refusing to expand, however there is no point to this other than sentimental value. I have never, in all my 300+ hours of Shogun 2, built a unique building or a hero unit. I don't think I've ever leveled a general or agent to max level either. 

2. In search of the full game experience, one will probably be tempted, as I was, to try the harder difficulties. This is where the real "fun" starts.

Shogun 2 attempts to make the game more difficult by boosting the AI and instilling it with ever more "anti-player" fervor. The already god awful diplomacy system breaks down completely on higher difficulties. 

AI factions will declare war on you under the most illogical of circumstances. Factions will send armies from across the map, leaving their homeland completely undefended, in an attempt at throwing more bodies at the player. They will break alliances and backstab you for no reason, for no advantage (other than making life difficult for the player) and no apparent penalty (whereas the player would receive large negative relation penalties for such behavior). 

Even when another AI faction threatens to dominate all of Japan, the other factions won't care and continue to barrel down on the player.

3. On higher difficulties the game devolves into a game of never-ending whack-a-mole. Since the AI is as god awful as the diplomacy system, it still generally fails to provide a challenge. With the massive economic and military boosts the AI gets, even AI factions with a single province will happily send stack after stack into your heavily defended positions, and it will not care.

Unfortunately, while these battles are generally easily won, the auto-resolve function does not agree. It barely seems to recognize any defensive advantage like when you are defending a castle or a river crossing. Thus, nearly every battle has to be fought manually. After one or two such battles, this becomes extremely tedious. 

There is no chance of playing a diplomatic or more slow, peaceful game, bringing me to my next point;

4. The only real threat is being swamped by countless AI stacks before you have the chance to reach "critical mass." On higher difficulties this "critical mass" is slightly bigger than on the lower ones, but not by much. 

Once it's reached, the game becomes trivial again and the campaign is essentially over. Because strategy, peace and diplomacy are not feasible options in this game, the goal is to reach critical mass as fast as possible. Any attempts at slowing down would result in you going to war with half the map, and having to manually fight off several AI stacks per turn.

As a result, campaigns on the harder difficulties tend to be only [i]slightly[/i] longer than on lower difficulty, [b]once again not allowing you to experience the more interesting features of the game.[/b]


This is Shogun 2 in a nutshell. A game that promises much, initially entrances the player, but ultimately fails to deliver satisfaction.

I'm sure that, in time, I will once again fall into the trap, and will once again quit the game unsatisfied. If you haven't bought this game yet, don't make the same mistake.

/rant

This is one of my most favorite Titles of the series. I started TW with the first Shogun oh so many years ago in 2001, and have been a faithful fan and player of all the titles of the series. 

While Shogun 2 is a much robust and evolved version of the first title, there are a couple of areas which I feel it was not able to replicate. There was a certain charm to move armies in the map of Shogun like chess pieces on its original Map that I felt Shogun 2 lacks in favor of the fully 3D map. The second area could be the battle AI and the formation mechanic. Formations seem to have less of an impact in Shogun 2. 

Other than these two elements, Shogun 2 is a great Game with much better expansions covering even the fall of the Samurai, adding naval battles and also Multiplayer. The attention to detail is worthy of Japan, from the Music to the authentic Graphical representation of the era, down to the inflections of the Diplomats and the Damyo.

The only thing that remains consists to take upon the challenge of unifying Feudal Japan under one's banner!

------------------------------------------------------------FRA-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Un très bon jeu, excellent de mon point de vue même.
Alors pourquoi un avis négatif ? Tout simplement que suite à la mise à jour mineur du 24/05/2023 la pop-up Mod Manager qui se lançait juste avant le jeu n'est plus. Du coup le jeu crash au lancement d'une partie, qu'elle soit nouvellement créée ou pas. 
Le passage dans les propriétés de l'onglet workshop n'y change pas grand chose et ne permet pas de régler quel mod on souhaite activer et quel autre ne l'est pas. Je n'ai pas testé le désabonnement de certains d'entre eux pour gérer les conflits mais je vous laisse faire le test vous-même si vous avez la foi.

Une solution en revanche fonctionnelle consiste à retourner dans les propriétés du jeu, onglet "Bêtas" et de sélectionner 'linux-pre-2022-update'. De cette façon les données modifiées retourneront à leur état d'avant patch, il sera nécessaire de laisser votre jeu réappliquer ces changements. Une fois fait, votre jeu est à nouveau opérationnel et la pop-up Mod Manager se lancera comme il faut, vous laissant le choix sur l'activation ou non de vos mods.

Une autre solution proposée par la communauté consiste à supprimer manuellement dans le fichier user.script.txt présent dans appdata/roaming/the creative assembly/shogun2/scripts le ou les mods pour ne lancer que ceux que vous voulez avoir. Je ne l'ai pas testée sachant que la première méthode est fonctionnelle et plus ergonomique :)

L'autre changement conséquent lié au patch est la suppression du chat pour les parties en ligne. Je n'en ai que rarement eu l'utilité personnellement mais je peux comprendre la frustration pour ceux ne voulant pas l'utilisation d'un moyen de communication tier qui était jusqu'à présent intégré nativement dans le jeu.

Je persiste à dire que ce jeu est vraiment excellent, malgré cette problématique, nous avons pour l'heure encore moyen de s'adapter et si vous n'y avez jamais joué, attendez une promo, il vaut vraiment le coup.


En espérant avoir pu vous être utiles, bon jeu à tous !

------------------------------------------------------------ENG-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A very good game, excellent in my opinion.
So why the negative review? Quite simply that following the minor update of 24/05/2023, the Mod Manager pop-up that launched just before the game is no longer available. As a result, the game crashes when a game is launched, whether newly created or not. 
Switching to the workshop tab properties doesn't change things much, and doesn't allow you to set which mod you want to activate and which you don't. I haven't tested the mod manager yet. I haven't tested unsubscribing some of them to manage conflicts, but I'll let you do the test yourself if you have the faith.

A solution that does work, however, is to go back to the game properties, "Betas" tab and select 'linux-pre-2022-update'. This will return the modified data to its pre-patch state, so you'll need to let your game re-apply these changes. Once done, your game is back up and running, and the Mod Manager pop-up will launch as required, giving you the choice of whether or not to activate your mods.

Another solution proposed by the community consists of manually deleting the mods you wish to have from the user.script.txt file in appdata/roaming/the creative assembly/shogun2/scripts. I haven't tested it, as the first method is functional and more ergonomic :)

The other consequential change linked to the patch is the removal of chat for online part. I've rarely used it myself, but I can understand the frustration for those who don't want to use a third-party means of communication that was natively integrated into the game until now.

I still say that this game is really excellent, despite this problem, we still have a way to adapt and if you've never played it, wait for a discount, it's really worth it.

Shogun II is , unfortunately , totally outdated. 
1- you can not trespass on others' lands. imagine you are besieging someone's castle, if you make peace with them, the game is going to teleport your army from their province to a random place in your own territory. 
2- the cavalry units in this game are very weak, a cheap spear unit (known as Yari Ashigaru) can easily defeat three elite cavalry units just by standing still and no , charging from rear wont work against them. 
3- the final stage of the game, is totally unrealistic and illogical. why should every weak & undeveloped faction declare war on you as the mightiest faction in the game instead of trying to negotiate some sort of a deal with you? this is not how politics works in real world. and it wasnt certainly the case in the actual history of Japan.
4- more on Yari Ashigaru, this unit is capable of beating everyone only by holding their spears and standing still. raising the question that why should even bother ourselves with downloading the hero units & paying extra cash for recruiting samurai units
5- the naval battles are completely unrealistic and totally unplayable . a/ imagine you want to move a couple of thousands of your soldiers , you are going to need a ship right? okay, lets have a trade ship. cheapest option available. then okay there are two trade ships of one of our enemies attacking us. we go to the battle. there is no sign of your thousands of katana samurai & bow samurais , they just dont exist. they are somewhere hidden in the ship . you lose the battle , oh my god , you lost all of your soldiers. the entire army is gone! 
b/ the ai is capable of spamming fleets to some absurd level which makes naval battles even more unplayable than you can imagine.

Total War: SHOGUN 2 is a triumph in the strategy genre, offering an immersive and authentic experience set in feudal Japan. The attention to detail in the historical accuracy, from the units to the landscapes, is remarkable. The gameplay mechanics are refined and polished, striking the perfect balance between turn-based strategy and real-time battles. The art direction is stunning, with beautifully crafted environments and meticulously designed units. The campaign is deep and engaging, allowing you to experience the intricacies of clan politics and warfare. With its challenging AI, rich storyline, and captivating multiplayer, Total War: SHOGUN 2 is a true gem for strategy enthusiasts.

So I've given CA a LOT of stick recently over their newer titles and felt it was about time I gave this game the plaudits it deserves. It's awesome, start to finish captures exactly what I want a TW game to be. I can slowly but surely craft my perfect generals and agents until they become unstoppable, battles are dynamic and always fun. The AI is capable of putting up a significant fight when on higher difficulties. 

The co-op campaigns are good and the game pace is managed very well. 

The technology aspects are good, but with a caveat that if you're playing on lower difficulties there's a good to strong likelihood that you'll win the game before reaching the bottom 2 layers of the tree itself.

The only minor gripes I have with the game are as follows:
 Agents are sometimes TOO powerful. If you haven't been nurturing at least 1 good ninja or metsuke from the beginning of the game and someone else has you will really struggle.

The morale mechanics in battle can go a bit awry. I've had examples of 200-300 ashigaru running away from 50 samurai. Which isn't completely insane, but what is insane is I was assaulting a town.... and my ashigaru decided to flee THROUGH the samurai they were supposedly running from (and still outnumbered 4-1)

Honestly though, I'm nitpicking... this game is still worth the price of any AAA title to this day and I'd happily pay it.

** UPDATE 12/05/23 **
Continuing on the subject of agents, I was surprised to learn the "Chances of success" number is actually completely fake. On my campaign I needed my agent to be successful in order to not lose a town. For the first time in a long and storied Shogun 2 career I decided to cheat and saved just before the agent action (67% chance of success). I'll admit it's possible I'm simply the unluckiest man on the planet, but I've so far reloaded the game and retried this action 25 times and gotten the exact same result every single time (failure but no harm to my agent).

The chances of that happening in a legitimate system are so vanishingly small there doesn't seem to be any other explanation other than that number is fake and in fact the game decides the outcome of agent actions based on (or at least heavily influenced by) factors which are hidden from the player.  

While that's quite disappointing, the game is nonetheless still good.

I love the total War Series and I have spend many hours in Rome 2 Total War.
But I am extremely disappointed in this game, even though I wanted to like it so bad.

The first half of the game I loved. Trying to carve out space for your clan in Japan, huge battles on Japanese castles with flaming arrows flying all around, making alliances and dealing with politics. It was great.

The second half of each game is terrible. It's when you hit a point called Realm Divided. When you claim too much land or try to take over Kyoto, basically every other clan magically allies with each other and declares war on you. Even when you become the Shogun. This results in you getting attacked from every direction and every front. And these other clans will never have peace with you for any offer, so the political aspect is thrown right out the window. This increased challenge would be welcomed but isn't feasible when you only can get up to a max of about 1/3 of japan before it begins. Again, every other clan is magically all in an alliance now and just hates you. IDK why they call it realm divided when the entire realm all unites just to fight you.

This would be doable, but a few other features ruin it for me. Eventually Christianity is introduced to Japan. The clans that adopt it can eventually send out missionaries. These missionaries can incite christian revolts. I had enemy clans attempt this 10 times, and every time it is successful. And then out of nowhere in a province that is 100% Buddhist or Shinto, a well trained army of over 2,000+ Christians rebels appears and instantly takes your town.

So while you are having a huge war on every border, the enemy Christian clans can send a cheap missionary and incite a max army size of rebels on a whim at barely any cost. 100% needs some balance changes.

Everything is great until you get to that realm divide point when politics are worthless. It is extremely frustrating and ruins all the fun of the game and realism. I consider myself a pretty alright player and was playing on hard difficulty up to this point. But once you get to the realm divide point I couldn't even do it on easy difficulty. Maybe I missed something in the game, maybe I just suck, I don't know. But I am for sure going back to Rome Total War instead of this.

shogun 2 is one the most well put together games I have know for this era of gaming, I almost consider it the last installment to the total war series prior to their revamp. it uses many of the systems from empire and medieval II.

I really recommend playing Rome remastered, Rome remastered (barbarians), Medieval II, Empire, shogun 2 (fall of the samurai) in that order. it basically spans 400 BC to 1900 AD pretty flawlessly as far as combat tactics are concerned. I really couldn't tell you what game best covers the 1900s forward and still maintains a firm grasp of tactics, strategies, and environmental aspects as well as the Total War series.

the "new" series (Rome II, Attila) I cannot recommend as much, not to say they are worthless, but all the Warhammer series, three kingdoms, and pretty much all the DLC/standalone extensions are pretty smart. that said there are plenty of issues with mechanics for each game, where the AI will game the system, there is a glaring historical inaccuracy (like in Attila), and mechanic problems where fluff doesn't match crunch or crunch doesn't match fluff. of cause cheesing the mechanics and making the map boundary counter a wall of flesh seems to work most of the time if you want to annoy the AI.

Shogun 2 (rise of the samurai) and Shogun 2 are really fun to play and playing them in the order of eras as apposed to release order doesn't effect enjoyment, though you will feel limited at first if you go in order of release.

One of the best total war games out there! Also one of the least diverse unfortunately. But with the more focused campaign Creative Assembly was able to focus more on overall gameplay rather than making a bunch of different cultures and diverse units. This means they have nearly perfected the overall feel and handling of the game from the way the battles handle to the crisp clean UI which does it's job while also looking great and matching the games tone. Not to mention this game boasts some of the best battle AI for any Total War game ( I know not saying much). One of the only negatives I have to say is that the naval battles aren't great. You'll usually lose more boats than you think you should which in turn leads to a lot of auto resolving.

I also have to mention that this game also has one of the best expansions to any Total War game, Fall of the Samurai! The expansion takes place in an entirely different era of Japan where gunpowder units rein supreme. But even then you can choose to stay traditional and use samurai units to charge into a hail of lead like you're reenacting a scene from the movie The Last Samurai! Fall of the Samurai really boasts some of the best gunpowder battles of any Total War game!

Been playing TW since Shogun 1 (I remember the previews and wait to it's release!) and FOTS is my favorite so far. 

It's essentially like if Shogun 2 and Empire Total War had a baby. 

Now if you're in between buying either Shogun 2 or FOTS (both are standalone)...I'd say it really comes down to whether you liked the gun/cannon-play of Empire? If you did, get FOTS. Though ultimately you should probably play both :) 

I liked the art-style of the unit/building cards more in Shogun 2, but apart from that: the "mean loudness" of the land/naval battles with guns/cannons, etc, a few small graphic tweaks, the diversity of the units, etc: FOTS has Shogun 2 beat.
A great game for those who played the original Shogun way back when and for newcomers too!

By far the shittiest total war game to date. Tried getting into it many times but i eventually get bored and uninstall.

On anything above Normal Difficulty (something 50%+ of the fanboys have never tried, look at steam achivements for this game) the AI is a flat out ret*rded warmonger, You can be the most powerful faction on the map and a AI can be the weakest faction in the game with a single town and the moment you move your armies away from it's border (AI always have radar cheat on this game and know where every single army you have are) he will instantly backstab you even if you are in an alliance. Diplomacy might as well not even exist in the game because AI will just attack you on a whim with ofc increased bias to target the player.

If you take a single City the next 3 factions bordering that City will declare war on you, and they will always be in alliances with 1-3 other factions.

If you are at war with several factions alone you might as well give up, they will cheat and know where your armies are at all times, and will *NEVER* i repeat *NEVER* accept peace unless you kill all their armies, and waltz up to their last City and besiege them, If you arent one turn away from eliminating them from the game they will almost never ask for peace, which means you can never Eliminate one of them because the second you start moving towards him the other rats in the throng will just pick at you from all sides.

AI will deny trade with you even if it benefits them because they would rather deny you resources than gaining more themselves.

Unit diversity is non existant, all factions play the same and most have pathetically tiny bonuses that have 0 impact.

The Actual battles AI is equally moronic, There are many cheese strategies you can abuse and AI just falls for it everytime.

Worst of all is the games obnoxious drone fanboy community, that spreads their sh*t everywhere, screeching how this pile of garbage is the best total war game whenever you try to discuss any other game in the franchise.

Been a total war fan since Rome Total war, and Shogun 2 is definitely extremely high on the list of all Total war games so far. 

The game excels at streamlining the campaign map management compared to other Total war games while adding depth to the mechanics involved with different strategies you take. Players won’t be overwhelmed at the start of the game with cluttered tabs or overlays.

The battles themselves are excellent as well. You have baseline units with counters for each as well as more expensive units that fall deeper into specific unit types. All factions have access to the same units to recruit with each faction getting bonuses Ro certain unit types. Battles can be as demanding/rewarding or as cheesy as you want, both options are available 🧀 The diplomacy is broken (a feature in almost every Total war game) and the Realm divide mechanic is brutal at times but not impossible. Those would be my only big gripes, but it’s a small list compared to other Total war titles.

While I would point new Total war players to the classics like Rome or Medieval 2 Total war, Shogun 2 is the most solid game for newer players based on it being more “modern” as well as the streamlined and effective way the game plays without overwhelming players or becoming dull.

As of this writing, i have logged in over 2,485 hours over the years.
I use this game to get me to sleep at night by leaving it on in the background as I slip away into la-la land. 
 Considering that this is a game about war and destruction, that statement makes me wonder what type of person I am. ;-)
Seriously, the flute section during the campaign map is so soothing and fits the Japanese setting perfectly. 
 For a Japan-o-phile all my life, this game hits all my happy points.  10/10 in all categories.

The quintessential Total War game and one of the finest games in RTS history. It hits every box: easy to learn and understand yet impossible to truly master, wonderful balancing (the first and only time in Total War history), and effectively endless replayability. It remains gorgeous after over a decade, its soundtrack is magnificent and gets play in the car, and it has that magic that some games do wherein it seems to generate stories and moments you will remember for a long, long time. There really is no weak point in Shogun 2, I can't come up with anything to critique. The visceral brutality and grit-tooth intensity of just the diplomacy could make for a wonderful game all on its own. If you remember it, go ahead, it's just as good as your nostalgia tells you. If you think it's interesting, do yourself a favor and pick up one of the very best strategy games of all time. If you're new to the genre, rest assured you can learn here in a straightforward, guided manner while simultaneously being forged in the hottest flame. Just uh... don't mind the memes. It ain't all of us.

It’s good, it’s really good. There’s no two ways about it. It’s simply one of the best total war games ever made. If you’re wondering if it still holds up in 2023, yes. Yes it does. And while both Shogun 2 and it’s DLC/ spin-off “Fall of the Samurai” are amazing im mostly focused on the base game you’re currently on the shop page for. 

The time period and conflict is basically a multi faction civil war in feudal Japan. But each clan is unique. Most of them have elite units or buffs that make it easier to composite your armies certain ways. The AI takes advantage of this. So while lots of units look the same there’s still a lot of diversity in the actual battles. 



Campaign
- The campaign map is beautiful and interactive. It’s relatively large with it being a very daunting task to “capture” the whole of Japan. 
-diplomacy, trade, nation building etc are the same as other games. Takes after the Empire TW idea of having a main castle/city with other resource gatherings and wealth creating buildings placed around larger regions. This makes it so you can cut off food to a region during sieges and take a more multi-dimensional path in war. 
- the voice lines for your generals and the tutorial women are glorious 
- Naval warfare exists, although Iv never found them particularly relevant. Still cool to have though, wooden box ships fighting each other with fire arrows is cool
- the time period is really cool and European traders + Wako pirates are factions in the campaign. 

Battles 
- AI is pretty good and if on high difficulty will utilize complicated tactics. 
- due to the aforementioned time period flint lock musket units and bowmen both have their place in battle and throughout the lengthy campaign. 
- there’s a surprising array of differing melee units from the various factions, this is especially true in the campaign as AI factions randomly build buildings that let them create a more diverse set of units. 

Multiplayer
- it exists and it for the most part works albeit a bit janky 
- multiplayer campaign is an absolute blast with the homies. You can help each other, fight against each other and even fight as the AI opponent in your friends battles. If speciation your friends they can gift you units to use so overall it’s pretty cool. (Multiplayer campaigns also count for campaign based achievements if you’re into that) 

Atmosphere
- it’s one of the more atmospheric Total Wars and will feel immensely different from TW Three Kingdoms, TW Rome 2, Empire TW, etc. 
- the art style, Japanese impressionist paintings on the loading screen, the stylistic choices of the user interface and even the  ever present animated face of your generals will make you truly feel like a feudal Japanese daimyo. 
- even if you know nothing about Japan or care about the historical significance, you can still march your army against other clans having fun. 

Steam deck
- This games does not work well on the steam deck. It crashes every couple min

The game is a shinning emerald in the ever growing sea of bland total war releases. (Y’all ever hear of Thrones of Britannia? No? Good, keep it that way) it’s a testament to timeless game design and replay ability. Right before I wrote this review I checked the multiplayer battles to see if there was any action. There were a few, hanging on. Not that it matters, you like most people probably just want to jump on to that amazing campaign

But the multiplayer (even if near death) does deserve praise for the extensive customization options for your general, and an intricate progression system. 

This game has European bought cannons, wooden Trebuchets, bomb throwers, peasant archers, samurai archers, katana men, peasants with matchlock muskets, peasants with spears, mounted archers, mounted samurai and so much more. 

If you’re wondering if it’s worth the $30 being over a decade old, I wouldn’t blame you and I can confidently say the enjoyment you will feel when your elite samurai take the capital and proclaim you shogun will make the price meaningless. 

Long live the Shogun!!!

A very slick upgrade to the classic Shogun game.

Amazing game even in 2023. But for micromanagers only, later it can be annoying.

Bad things
Naval battles suck a lot, autoresolve help just with part of it. You chase ships around the map, because they avoid conflict and retreat very far away, you usually do not reach them in the same turn. And next turn it repeats. For armies, you can use ninja sabotage army to avoid its retreat, but for fleets, there is no option. And experience do not improve accuracy of ships...

There is no cities overview, so you need to check each of them separately (there are 60 required for long campaign)

In battle, it is not clear where your troops can go and where cannot. In hilly terrain it can be frustrating and break perfect plan quickly.


The good
Combat is great, basic units can be useful even in late game if used correctly (yari wall).
Units feels nicely balanced, best units are better but usually with lower numbers and with twice as much basic units they can still loose.
Campaign is loooong, but can be frustrating sometimes because of mechanics above
Regions are special and using them correctly helps a lot (e.g. armored ashigarus)

Shogun 2 is like the inverse of medieval 2. While the campaign is terrible, it all pays off in the combat. Unfortunately, each campaign boils down to a 1v1, with every other faction serving as mere obstacles. I understand that this is what total war has been building up to, with Warhammer 2 serving as the peak. I just wish there was more to it than just an excuse to create insurmountable odds for the player to overcome. As is, this game is only worth buying if you're already heavily invested in the time period, or you want to revisit something a little more simple after playing the Warhammer series. With the lack of unique units and storylines to play with, this game will not try to invest you. At least this game proves that medieval 3 as a concept isn't so far-fetched of an idea

I hadn't played this since 2016, but had a nostalgic desire to do so this afternoon. While the graphics are a bit dated, the game play is still superb.

The DLC available is good, the strategy and battle tactics simulations are good, the art and music is fun. 

Overall this is a great total war game.

The only downside to this one is that it is still one of the older games where provinces owned by military allies do not count towards your victory condition, resulting in you having to attack your allies at some point.

The basic Shogun 2 is very good, better than most Total War Games, since in my opinion, it’s more complex and has more possible strategies, with a mix of old and new (guns, etc.) technologies. The game seems to run smoother too. It’s also a very different setting, with a lot of historical detail, which makes it interesting.
But don’t get The Fall of the Samurai. It’s very propagandized with the horrible westerner there to ruin Japan, forcing terrible goods and liberties on them when everyone was just singing smurfily, instead of before - being enslaved by the Shogun and daimyos and stagnating. It lost its credibility.

This game is effectively when the series reached its real peak: Taking every kind of unit in later games and balancing them perfectly. From a classic 'medieval' formation to literally a pike and shot formation. 
You can really have challenges that others have never given me, and you can really tell when you get into a multiplayer fight. With effectively a chess match between an opponent, making constant back-and-forth skirmishes.

Alright, Now here's some random advice for some fun:
() If you get bored of vanilla, add the extra provinces and clans mod: 
It can really drown you and if you're like me its alot of fun
() Try fall of the samurai afterwards; Its fun in...its own way, but is less chess, more 'super Napoleon'. Its also less paced or challenging
()Add the FOTS mods as well, especially if you have to deal with a western front in your strategies with constant sieges. A bit of a warning though; It makes a one sided fight even more of a meat grinder: If you thought 'pikes in front of walls, guns on top' is overpowered, then these forts make them much worse.

I enjoy these total war titles... But I think Shogun 2 by far is the most brutal and exciting of them all... Playing previous total war titles I didn't expect much except skins and voices to be different, I expected the core game mechanic to be the same... 

For example...

I didn't expect bow units to be devastating... My first battle, I was shocked... Sucking down a drink, snacking on some fries, sending my yari units in to slice up some enemy bow units... I had very few bow units and was lightly invested in ranged units... My yari troops marched to their deaths under a hail of enemy arrows... I shot soda snot and choked on my fries as I bared witness to the murder of my troops...

Samurai units are also pretty brutal... but you kinda get the idea later that powerful units come at a heavy cost of food and money...

Regardless of all that, I was shook... I got sucked into this title off and on for YEARS!!!

If you buy it full price or on sale, and you like RTS games, you'll not be disappointed...

If I had to compare Shogun 2 to a food, I would compare it to bland porridge. Porridge is healthy, it's easy to prepare and eat. But without anything to give it flavour, you're going to get tired of it real quick. I’ve heard that Fall of the Samurai is much better, but it’s something that I think still has some of the core issues I’ve listed below so I’m not in any rush to get around to it. The main frustrations I had with the game are as follows. 

Lack of faction diversity. All factions in this game, bar the Ottomo and the Ikko Ikki, play more or less exactly the same. They all have the same end goal, tech tree, religion and are all Japanese. The only thing differentiating them apart are the occasional slight changes to core units to give them +2 melee charge or cheaper recruitment, or something along those lines. There isn't even anything to represent China or Korea, despite the historical Korean invasion of 1592-1598 potentially lending itself well to this game. Furthermore, the European influence of the Portuguese is only limited to several units for the Ottomo, they don't even show up as their own faction! It's not like in Empire Total War, a game that is panned by all Total War players, where every faction gets some truly unique units, religion and voice lines. Could you imagine playing Medieval, Empire or Napoleon, with all nations replaced by the British? That's what playing Shogun 2 feels like, it has very limited replayability. 

Boring tech tree. Getting to the mid/lower parts of the tech tree doesn’t really reward you with better units like it does in Empire. Instead, most units are unlocked at the early-mid game which means that there isn’t much incentive to focus on tech expansion, which you couldn’t even if you wanted since you can only research one tech at a time. Some siege/gunpowder units are definitely not worth trying to get, as Matchlock Ashigaru, European Cannons andFire Projecting Mangonels are all pretty bad with much better options available.

Ashigaru spam. You’ll be seeing stacks of Yari/Bow ashigaru (i.e spear/bow peasantry) in the early game and sometimes even into the late game, where they have no right being there. This isn’t made any better by the fact that types of units (sword/spear infantry, cav, siege, bows) all need their own buildings to be trained from, which thus makes it a whole lot easier for the AI to spam them. Even on Legendary difficulty in realm divide I’ve seen ashigaru making up half of a full stack army, even though Katana/Naginata samurai are much better. If you love fighting against peasants, this is the game for you. 

Removal of features/dumbing down from previous Total Wars. No tech/province trading means that you’ll sometimes be signing peace treaties on poor terms, as sometimes the AI simply has no money to give.  Naval battles are even worse than in Empire, here you’ve traded in cannons for bows and it is as painful and boring as it sounds. I once spent at least 15 minutes trying to take out a medium bune with a cannon bune, where it didn’t even seem to be close to being destroyed. Just pass on the naval battles, they are awful here. Granted, the perks for agents/generals/family certainly made them more fun to use as opposed to Empire, so I should give credit where credit is due. 

Also, blood pack DLC is cancer, it should be base game. At least put it on sale sometimes CA.

All in all, I’m not really a fan of Shogun 2. If you like the idea of a game set in feudal Japan focused solely on the more traditional ways of fighting, then you’ll love this game. Otherwise, you’ll be getting bored real quick with the lack of replay value.

I love the game but it has some inexcusable issues. Borderless fullscreen mode is not supported, and the supported fullscreen mode (exclusive fullscreen) has serious issues. The game has trouble focusing back if you tab out so it can be really difficult to get back into the game if you check something else or click on another window if you have a multi-monitor setup. Naval battles have broken AI (trying to bait it into a trap can soft lock the battle) or sometimes the game will say you had a "decisive victory" but say you somehow lost half your naval units out of nowhere. On high DPI displays, the game will support your high resolution (1440p or above) but does not have any UI scaling options. There is a mod to increase font size a bit but it's frankly not sufficient (especially above 1440p). There are games much older than this that do have UI scaling options or automatically adjust your UI scale depending on your resolution.

I may continue playing the game but these issues unfortunately present a major hindrance to my enjoyment of it

The best Total War for its time, still holds up today.

The unit roster is small, even if it's expected given the relatively small and homogeneous region this grand strategy encompasses.  Internal management of nations is better than most Total Wars, with mechanics like food and buildings implemented well here.  Battles have a pleasant flow to them, with archers commanding the field significantly.  Volleys of arrows are still beautiful to watch.

What is the greater tragedy?  That there is no Shogun 3, or that should they make one, there'd be no chance of it being this good?

MUST MISS DLC for this game:

Total War: SHOGUN 2 - Dragon War Battle Pack (This DLC is already part of the Fall of the Samurai game which is basically part of Shogun 2 as it is a standalone expansion).  You already know if you want this game or not so I'm just going to tell you everything you need to know:

DLC that actually adds content:

Total War: SHOGUN 2 – Otomo Clan Pack DLC
Total War: SHOGUN 2: Saints and Heroes Unit Pack
Total War: SHOGUN 2 - The Ikko Ikki Clan Pack
Total War: SHOGUN 2 - Sengoku Jidai Unit Pack
Total War: SHOGUN 2 - Rise of the Samurai Campaign
Total War: SHOGUN 2 - The Hattori Clan Pack

DLC that is purely cosmetic:

Total War: Shogun 2 - Blood Pack DLC

Then there's the "Fall of the Samurai" standalone expansion.  If you search for it in Steam you'll see the game and then you'll see what looks like 4 DLC's for it, however each of those 4 DLC items actually comes with the "Fall of the Samurai" so you only need Fall of the Samurai and you'll have all 4 of those.

All in all, you can expect to pay about $23 for Shogun 2, all of the DLC that actually has content, + the Fall of the Samurai expansion.  It comes to about $26 if you care about the cosmetic "Blood Pack DLC," but honestly there will always be better ways to spend $3 on Steam.  That's at the 75% discount anyway, which I've seen this game discounted at twice in the past 3 months.

Don't waste your time researching if a ~$1 piece of DLC is "worth it," it isn't worth the man hours to save that dollar anyway (especially since at least 80% of the time you're probably going to get that DLC you're considering anyway so really you only stand to save 20 cents in the long run).  I spent this time so you don't have to.

I have owned Shogun 2 since the release and it has undergone some major overhauls in that time, however, one thing has stayed the same throughout: The game is great.

I will say this right away, for some people this game is not their cup of tea; if you do not like strategy/management combined with Turn-based/RTS then this game is not for you (Any de-sync issues that originally existed have been eliminated, and even if an issue does ever crop up, the host call always share the save file to fix the issue).


However, if you DO like Turn-based/RTS, I cannot recommend this game any higher. 
This is hands down one of my FAVOURITE strategy games of all time; I have had some epic battle moments with this game and I quite enjoy the RPG/planning elements on the campaign map. I've known people to play this game purley for the battles. I would recommend getting some mods to improve AI/balance/gameplay, such as Radious or Darthmod (whichever you prefer; personally I use Radious as there are many different versions).

Pros:
+Excellent turn-based/RTS elements
+Choose from many different factions each with their own specialties and flavour (more with mods or DLC)
+Compatible with many different PC system specs
+Online Multiplayer + Campaign Co-op
+Very high replayability
+Tons of mods to allow for greater customization / tweaking / balancing
+Blood & Gore DLC: 'Watch as your samurai stabs an enemy Daiymo in the gut then slices his head off as he falls to his knees'  :)


Cons:
-Campaigns can potentially take a long time; do not forget though you can always auto-resolve battles to speed things up
-AI can be weak/cheesed in some situations (improved with mods)


Overall, I have very few gripes with this game. After playing it for so long I can say for certain if you like a mix of turn-based/RTS games, you will fall in love with shogun 2.

Returning to the artistic masterpiece Shogun 2 has been a treat. The graphics are a solid 10 after 11 years due to the unique approach CA took when designing this game. The challenge of the game is fair to the player, but on legendary you'll need to use all of the game's concepts in a cohesive way to beat the ultimate challenge. Dialogue and cutscenes are immersive and fun, with the overall experience of the game making you feel like you are in a total war.

Some would say Realm Divide is an unfair mechanic, but I think this helps resolve some of the staleness of the end game (auto-resolve>auto-resolve>auto-resolve etc).

Overall I would rate Shogun 2 a 10 for graphics, a 9 for balanced gameplay and a 10 for immersion. Truly a unique game worth playing.

I often think OLD GOOD | NEW BAD, but I believe this sequel does justice to its predecessor. Shogun 1 Total War and the Mongol Invasion expansion pack were the first original games I ever owned in my life. I must have played that game for 10+ years, and even tho I loved Rome: Total War, my heart always returned to Shogun 1. 

Last week, I loaded Shogun 2 for the first time, and I admit Shogun 2 is an improvement in almost every aspect over the original game, it does lack certain 'soul' such as missing the emissaries coming into the war-room to discuss diplomacy with you, I also remember the ninja videos being cooler than what we have now, I have yet to see any geishas in shogun 2, and the original soundtrack being delegated to Loading Screen Music pains my heart. But my god, there is no greater feeling than literally headshotting the enemy general with a cannon ball or Yari-lock the entire enemy army to death. 

Naval battles kinda sucked tho.

There was no TW like this before, and none came after. None stand on this giant's shoulders.

From the infantry, to the siege maps, to the artillery, to the cavalry, to the archers... name something that doesn't spark joy.

the only thing i can't recommend is getting expanded japan mods and trying a legendary Tokugawa or Mori campaign: you [i]will[/i] get folded like origami.

I proved myself that I am the worst at strategy game, yet this game makes me want to conquer japan further
Slow start at early game, but when it reach mid-end game. Oh boy does the game starts to throw not just rocks at you, but a whole chunk of it to your face.

Though with perfect planning, try and error. You would eventually get the hand of it.

Gameplay
----------

You play as either the 12 factions in the game, fighting over conquer over Japan by taking over the capital and holding it for a year, which then you would win the war afterwards

Each factions has their own traits, their advantages and their own disadvantages. No matter which factions you pick you will have trouble along the way, but that is the fun of it. Though picking the easier starting factions would be slightly more forgiving and allow you to learn the game till you are ready for a more challenging start

Once you have picked a faction, you have numbers of problems, just like in real life.. You have to manage your resources well, two most important are gold and your food source. Without those, you will be broke and hungry daimyo with your people chunking rocks at your face. 

However, managing this two resources often than not can be rather complicated at times. Recruit too much soldiers? Upkeep. Trying to expand and upgrade your castle? Food upkeep. This are the things that make this game fun to manage and plan ahead when you most needed

Your army, research and development
----------

There are lots of variants and types of army you can recruit to fight for you and expand further on, you can even recruit agents within the game to do non-combat roles most of the time to sabotage your enemies or allies alike if you want to. But that comes at the cost of needing specific buildings, specific research before you can reach to that stage, that would take lots of turns. But once you have reach that stage of development, you will feel completely powerful and have an edge over the others, its a feeling that I can't describe it but once you have reach there, you will understand why

AI
---------

When I said the AI don't really play fair, they often don't, they will find ways to screw you over, be it disrupting your trade routes or simply attacking you because they do not like you or want to take your very nice lands, but you can do the same to them as well if you want to and have the capability to, they basically force you to adapt to tough situation when you least expect it

DLC
--------

I haven't played rise of the samurai so I can give a proper review on that one but I was fortunate enough to be able to play fall of samurai, I would give a simple review on it in word. "Guns".

Final review
--------
Do I recommend this game? Does it enable your thirst for conquest?

Well, this game can be frustrating at times but once you have crossed over that herd of flames and bullshit. Its the best damn feeling you will ever get in this game.

Call me a weeb, but this is my personal favorite total war and what I pick to be the best historical game. Fall of the Samurai is the single best total war expansion ever. All of the factions are fun and interesting. And none of them are overly similar. 

The only real things I have issue with are the parts of every total war game that suck. Diplomacy is a joke, it doesn't work. It never did, and it never will. They have never figured out naval battles. And Playing on the hardest difficulties is a joke. It stacks buffs for the AI, nerfs for you, and they spawn full armies out of nowhere even with no money. 

And CA never drops the prices. This game came out 11 years ago, it should not be $30.

Shogun 2 is a turn based strategy game set during the Japanese civil war. It is a very fun empire building type game. The in game graphics are really good and the battles are fun and tactical. With two awesome expansion packs (one set in the late 19th century, if you like the Napoleonic era, I recommend you pick up the fall of the Samurai expansion), Total War, Shogun 2, is a great game, especially if you like the Samurai Sengoku Period. However, Steam workshop mods are often necessary to shake the game up a bit. 

Features: 
-Steam workshop
-DLC's 
-Grand campaign map
-Highly detailed real time battles
-Historical scenarios
-Multiplayer campaign

Rating: 4.4/5 a very fun game, but has a good share of flaws and eventual boredom.

My descent down the rabbit hole of Total War began with this game. It feels authentic for the time and while it isn't Medieval, the War for Japan really is something to be delighted about. Maybe it's also personal preference, but your battles feel earned compared to later ones especially on higher difficulties. The longer you continue to fight, the harder it gets with Religion, raiding, and just total standstills at time. 

Agents are necessary to maintain control of the Campaign Map. Shinobi to Assassinate and Sabotage, Metsuke to stop enemy agents, Priests to maintain public order, without them, you're screwed. And you have to start early to have an advantage over everyone else.

My biggest complaint is the Fame system. The more battles you win and more factions you destroy, the more fame you get. Eventually, you'll trigger an end game where EVERYONE wants your blood. Any carefully crafted Alliances are shattered and any trade agreements are worthless. Meaning you have to rely on brute force and strategy.

Though becoming Shogun is made all the more worth it after endless turns of battle.

This game is fun, I played it in multiplayer mode a few times. It took two times to get the hang of things so it's not too difficult. It's an RTS, you can try to play as a passive trader, a conqueror or something in-between. You can talk with nearby provinces to persuade them to your side or persuade them to become enemies with your enemies. The AI is not super smart when you battle it but your friends in multiplayer can play as the AI you are going up against.

There are a few negative issues with the game in multiplayer. My game did crash on startup, plus the screens where you choose where you can start on the map didn't work for me in one match. A few other popup screens in the game also were broken so I couldn't make certain choices in others. My friend told me that I was supposed to see an option screen so I expected it. The screen was there but there was nothing to click, I realized after that it was probably a bug related to the others for me. My computer isn't old so I think it has to do with the age of this game and a DirectX incompatibility on my part. So it is fun, but you may end up in a situation where multiplayer bugs limit what you can do.

This is a great game!  Been playing it for years!

I recommend this game to any player who is seeking an entertaining time with lots of unit types, including fun spies and ninjas.  There is tactics and strategy nicely balanced out and both land and sea battles.  You can guide your Clan as you like, making war or peace or trading treaties, etc. with others all at a turn-based pace that allows for thinking about your choices and then carrying them out.

You can carry out battles automatically or command the troops directly so there are some RTS qualities thrown in here and there but not face-paced FPS type action.  But that's what I like.  This is a game for when you want to relax and rule and direct rather than chop, hack or shoot one on one.

Pick it up and enjoy!

My first ever introduction to the total war game franchise was Shogun 2. It remains to be a great game after all this time.


This game sparked a love for RTS games within me and brought a lot of enjoyment. It's a solid game with a very unique game-play between the fall of samurai (FOTS) and the Shogun campaign. The Shogun combat is much faster and balanced to a rock and paper vs scissors formula. As well, the FOTS combat feels very devastatingly good. I love seeing riflemen flatten a cavalry charge or when canons blow up a castle sky high. The mini-cinematic make the world more immersive.

Now returning to this game, since I first played, it makes me appreciate more how well Shogun 2 was crafted with care. The newer total war games have lost their charm; this is the peak of Creative Assembly creation.

Shogun 2 in 2022.

I came to the total war series late, and I only got around to Shogun 2 this year.

I always heard Shogun 2 was the best game in the series. I had a passing interest in the Sengoku period. So why did I avoid it for so long?

I had an odd misconception about what the game was really about, that kept me from giving it a chance. You see, in Real Life, my father was killed in a pointless and stupid war. Meaningless butchery has always offended me, even in fiction. I thought the Sengoku period was fascinating, but I had no interest at all in pretending to be some feudal Daimyo.

Even in a computer game, I have to feel like there is some greater purpose behind the fighting. Some ideological conflict that can only be resolved by war. And so far  as I could see, it made no difference which family of useless, narcissistic sociopaths got to exploit, rape and murder the productive segment of the nation.

What piqued my interest, was when I found out I could play as the Ikko-Ikki; a group with which I actually sympathized. Fanatic Buddhists who said FEUDALISM SUCKS and tried to burn the whole rotten system down. Naturally, they weren't too popular with the establishment.

And sure, for the average peasant, it probably didn't make much difference if you were being squeezed by an entitled ass or a delusional monk, but at least the Ikkis offered hope for a better future.

It isn't just the Ikko-Ikki though; there's plenty of ideological conflict in the game, and some of it isn't immediately obvious. I'm going to break down the factions to explain what I see as real differences between them. And bear in mind, I'm talking in-game, which is only loosely based on the real clans (some of which still exist today).

The Traditionalists: With their obsession on personal honor and loyalty, and the cult of the sword, the Shimazu are the embodiment of the old ways. They've held the same territory in the south of Kyushu for centuries, to the point where they're pretty much a nation into themselves. The Takeda clan is their counterpart in the north. The traditionalists just want the civil war to finally end, so they can go back to reading poetry and tending the graves of their ancestors.

The Outsider clans: The Mori, Chosokabe, Uesugi and Date are also very conservative, but in one way or another they exist on the frontiers of Japanese society. They trace much of their ancestry back to the Chinese, Koreans, or even aboriginal people who lived in Japan since the stone age. They're physically distant from the Imperial court, a bit rough around the edges, and in the case of the Mori they have extensive contact with various barbarians. They tend to have unconventional, oddly specialized militaries.

The innovators: The Tokugawa, Oda and Hojo are traditional clans, but they are more ready than most to adapt to new ways of doing things. In the case of the Oda, they're more willing to rely on peasant soldiers. This means their army is more meritocratic generally. (One Oda vassal, Toyotomi Hideyoshi, was born a peasant and rose to be, for a short time, de facto ruler of Japan). The Hojo are masters of architecture and gunpowder engines.

The Radicals: The Ikko-Ikki follow a strange sect of Buddhism. Their fanatical followers want to bring down the old order and create a heavenly brotherhood on Earth. The Otomo are even more radical; they're bent on making Japan a Christian nation. (Christianity is much more firmly established in Shogun 2 than it was in the same time frame in real life- the real life Otomi were tolerant of Christianity but not wholly converted to it, and Christianity spreads much more quickly in game than it actually did).

The Outcasts: The Hattori are the least "historical" of the factions in the game. In game they're the leaders of the Iga Ikki, which was a loose confederation of peasants and Jizamurai, whose skill in guerrilla warfare gave rise to the myth of the ninja. In real life they just wanted to be left alone, but in game they have the chance to spread their guerrilla insurgency across all Japan.

And now that I understand each faction better, it's easy for me to slip into the role playing aspect of the game. I've played most factions and each feels pretty different, on and off the battlefield.

I wouldn't recommend the game to anyone who is offended by gross historical inaccuracies- there's the usual CA silliness in regards to not understanding how pre-modern weapons and tactics work. The tactical battles are still the best part of the game, though also a bit frustrating- the land battles are much too fast, and the AI tactics amount to either standing on top of the steepest hill in the game and refusing to budge or having the entire army charge at once. To the point where most battles remind me of that monty python sketch where a bunch of old ladies say they're going to re-enact the attack on pearl harbor, but it just consists of them screaming and hitting each other with their purses. And, by contrast, the naval battles are much, much too slow, especially in the early game where you're trying to sink enemy vessels with bows and arrows and you haven't yet figured out the secret of making fire.

So yeah, deeply flawed, but still better than any of the other Total War titles.

Game design like this makes you question whether or not anyone tested the game before it was released. However, this is not a new release, it's been out for years. The primary feature of the campaign is that after your clan attains a certain level of power, all other factions declare war on you. This is referred to as the "realm divide." If this happened after you controlled say 40-60% of the map, it would be okay, however because your prominence increases each time you take a province or win a battle, the realm divide is often triggered at a point where victory is not possible. Further, something missing from all total war games of this era is decent diplomacy. If you have a vassal state, the ai does recognize that if they declare war on that state, you are also called into war. So each time you create a vassal, the ai recognizes the vassal as a weak state and immediately declares war. Further there a few features to improve relations, place trade embargoes, join wars, or enforce peace, as would exist with comparable games like Europa Universalis. Lastly, by comparison to other total war games, cavalry is almost useless in this. Often four or five cavalry units are required to destroy one infantry unit. The graphic designers, the sound designers, the software developers all did a great job with this — but the game designers themselves, or at least the managers of the game designers, did not put thought into this game.

I think Napoleon is the best overall Total War, simply because of the amount that you can do, and the flexibility of where the campaign goes. Shogun 2, FOTS, however, is a close second, and is particularly notable for its naval combat and far more devastating (possibly *too* devastating) artillery.

It bears mentioning, though, that one of the things that holds FOTS back is that same naval warfare - specifically on the campaign screen. Simply put: it is far too easy for the AI to just sail around your fleets, blockade your ports, and bankrupt you without any real opportunity for counterplay. In other TW games, this really isn't possible, since you are able to safeguard your ports with relative ease (given a significant [but not ludicrous] investment in navies0. But in FOTS, you either slay every single enemy fleet taking some long route through deep water to strike at your ports, or you lose. And that... kind of sucks.

On the whole, though, it's still a great game.

Total War: SHOGUN 2


Pros -

#1.Still decent graphics for 2020

#2.Difficult to become shogun on normal difficulty.It is not easy and that is good.

#3.Many units and upgrades

#4.Your strategy is very important

#5.I like the music

#6.There is Multiplayer but I never tried it


Cons-


#1.My biggest problem with this game is that you can have the best army and still get killed by their assassin and it can kill all the progress and time you put into the game to get to that point.

I am not even calling it unrealistic it is just lame when it happens.I understand we can do it back to them but I wish they were not so OP when maxed out.


#2.The time limit to become shogun

I had this same problem with Empire total war. I dont like the main game having a time limit.I understand that in real life there is time limits as we die of old age and that there can be a certain about of time to do things.

It does not really apply to either game though as if you/your people/country are trying to take over everything even if you personally die it does not mean your people/country are going to stop doing it and they have to still stop you.

I understand the time limit speeds things along but I would have removed it and made it more like Rome 2 where there is no time limit like that.


#3.The AI can be stupid

This is how all total war games are but it should be said when it happens.This is why some players only do multiplayer battles only.


#4.That everyone turns on you when the shogun makes you the enemy


This just isnt realistic.I understand that it can make the game harder and more of a challenge and some like that but if someone was always your ally/friend and one day the shogun says that we are now their enemy for them to just agree with that could get their whole civilization destroyed by us.

It would be like declaring war against a friend and knowing he could burn your cities to the ground easily but the shogun told you to so you have to.



The Bottom Line -


Total War: SHOGUN 2 is a fun turn based strategy game.I got enjoyment out of it but I still like Rome 2 more.

I would get SHOGUN 2 on a steam deal and they even do free weekends with it sometimes.

Watch some youtube gameplay of it if you still not sure.
