Awesome and fun experience in an immensely interesting time period and setting.

As a game it plays as a mix between empire and Medieval 2 - but it does have the worst features of both of those game; from empire randoms will declare war on you and travel across the map to wipe you and it can be tedious. From medieval you have an ai that does some silly things and that can be cheesed (I guess like all total wars haha). 

But it's a fantastic mix of both these games and it comes together in the fall of the samurai dlc which adds a fun diversity to the vanilla game with more developed gunpowder combat. 

The vanilla itself is superb, I'm a huge fan, even with the cheating on the legendary difficulty - it's done in a way that makes it very challenging yet not outrageous. Can have armies without generals, agents are nuanced as are the units (blade, spears, cavalry, missile cavalry, missiles, muskets and artillery).

I think this is a superb title and is worth a playthrough - plus it has multiplayer. 

Challenging fun title, Rise of the Samurai was particularly difficult. Remember although everyone remembers your Daimyo, you should never forget the Yari Ashigari that propped them up - probably the best (at least cost effective) unit in total war history

Total War Shogun 2, like version 1, has endless replay possibilities.

Shogun Total War was my first entry into the Total War franchise. I still love Shogun Total War Collection, the original version or v1.  I have MTW and ETW.

In Shogun 2, the feel of the more recent Total War games are vividly apparent, and easy to get right into play. But there are things I miss from STW1 that is absent or limited in STW2: STW allowed unlimited ninja and shinobi agents, whereas STW2 limits to just 5 ninja (unrealistic for playing Hattori clan) and no shinobi agents; and in STW you could have multiple katana hero units, where in STW2 you can only have 1 katana hero, bow and yari heros.

The main thing is miss from STW1 is the throne room and the really great ingame video, especially the master sword dojo video showing the 7 cut form.

I really love the ingame music. I bought the soundtrack so I could listen offline.

I play STW2 by hooking up my gaming desktop to a 55 inch 4K TV - playing on a big screen results in a total immersion experience.

I really hope that CA will remaster STW2 into STW3.

This is the best rts game I have played to date.

I received the base game free but willingly bought the dlcs as well as other games in the series.

This game combines the political and economical aspects of running a state, along with recruiting and using the armies of the time period. You can easily field hundreds of units just fine on a mid tier computer and watch as each man fights for their lives and their clan with everything they have.

This game has samurai, spearmen, cavalry, bows, guns, cannons, and more. You can do land battles, sieges, ship battles, and more.

This game is a must buy for history lovers and strategy games alike.

The final thing I would like to mention is the largest 2 dlcs add entire new campaigns in different time periods, the better of the two being the fall of the samurai. That campaign is set during the boshin war and has more modern gun and cannon  gameplay unlike the base game.

A truly fantastic game, get it!

Been playing through all the game, all 3 campaigns in co-op with my friend. We love all kinds of games, but one of the best series is the Total War series. We played through this one first of all, and plan to move on with the Warhammer titles, probably after Three Kingdoms.
I just wanted to make clear that we like these games. But this shit... This is just ridiculous. The AI is cheating as hell, not in a fun way. We are playing on hard, for some challenge, but not overwhelming. We have experience, but we cannot do much about things that are just straight up cheating. Enemy armies just spawning basically, ships coming out of nowhere (we literally had ships spawning in from a faction that didn't have any ports).
The amount of this is just so overwhelming that it ruins the fun completely. WE made it fun, because we are long-time friends, and we made a joke of everything, but there was a point when we got to the Fall of he Samurai campaign that we couldn't take anymore. We didn't finish yet, but it's pretty much in the next 10-15 turns what's happening, then we decide if we continue, or just quit completely.
I don't even want to imagine what it would be like on legendary difficulty. People that can bear that shit have my honest respect
All-in-all, it's not a bad game, but because of the AI I cannot recommend. Please just get me a title that has a somewhat decent AI that is reasonable, and doesn't just use infinite resources to spawn in armies every turn out of nowhere. Make it use resources, have limits to money, and tech (having a legendary dojo built in the 20th turn is just wow).
If the AI will improve ever, then I will be open to recommending it to anyone.
Multiplayer is fun though, but only because it doesn't have an AI to deal with, if I lose at least I know I fucked up, or the enemy was better than me.

edit: We abandoned that campaign, and started anew with new strategy.

Kangen makan curry rice ala Jepang? Akhir pekan ini bisa bikin sendiri. Dengan bumbu kari siap pakai, curry rice dengan daging sapi bisa mudah dimasak sendiri.
Curry rice atau kare raisu merupakan salah satu makanan Jepang populer di dunia. Berupa nasi putih yang disiram saus kari keockelatan kental. Bisa dipadukan dengan chicken katsu, potongan atau irisan daging dan sayuran.

Berbeda dengan kari di berbagai negara seperti Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia yang umumnya berkuah encer dan memakai santan. Kari Jepang lebih kental karena memakai tepung maizena sebagai pengentalnya
Bumbu kari Jepang dijual dalam bentuk bongkahan yang sudah dicampur pengental. Tinggal dimasukkan ke dalam rebusan daging dan sayuran saja. Bumbu ini juga ada beragam tingkat kepedasan.

Baca juga: Satu Menit Bisa Menikmati Chicken Katsu Curry Khas Jepang Ini

Sudah tak sabar ingin puas makan curry rice di rumah? Berikut ini resep dan tipsnya. Yuk, bikin!

Resep Curry Rice ala Restoran Jepang
Total Waktu Penyajian : 30 Menit
Untuk Penyajian : 4 Porsi
Judul Resep : Resep Curry Rice ala Restoran Jepang
Kategori : Daging
Masakan : Curry Rice
Durasi Persiapan : 15 Menit
Durasi Masakan : 15 Menit
Total Durasi : 30 Menit
Bahan :
500 g nasi putih
Beef Curry:
500 g daging has sapi, potong dadu sedang
2 sdm minyak sayur
100 g bawang bombay, iris kasar
1 siung bawang putih, memarkan
2 potong (cube) besar bumbu kari Jepang pedas sedang
2 buah kentang, kupas, potong dadu sedang
2 buah wortel, kupas, potong kasar
1 sdt gula pasir
Cara Membuat :
Didihkan air secukupnya dalam panci. Masukkan potongan daging, rebus dengan api kecil hingga daging empuk dan kuah susut setengahnya.
Tumis bawang bombay dan bawang putih hingga kuning dan wangi. Angkat.
Masukkan ke dalam panci berisi rebusan daging. Didihkan kembali.
Masukkan bumbu kari, wortel dan kentang.
Masak dengan api kecil hingga kuah kental, daging, kentang dan wortel lunak. Matikan api.
Taruh nasi di piring cekung. Tuangkan kari daging di atasnya.
Sajikan segera.
Tips:

1. Bumbu kari Jepang untuk curry rice biasanya dijual dalam bentuk cube atau brick atau kotak dikemas kardus. Bentuknya bukan bubuk tetapi pasta yang membeku. Selain bumbu kari juga sudah dicampur dengan bahan pengental sehingga tak perlu ditambahkan lagi. Tersedia rasa pedas, sedang dan pedas ringan.
2. Gunakan bumbu sesuai dengan petunjuk takaran dalam kemasannya. Bumbu ini sudah bisa dibeli di toko online dengan harga terjangkau.
3. Kekentalan kuah kari bisa disesuaikan selera. Jika suka pekat bisa ditambahkan bumbu dan dimasak hingga air susut dan mengental.

This game is so much fun to figure out and make different types of armies, some better (yari ashigaru spear wall formationg) some worse, and be able to defend and attack varies castles and battle it out on different battlefields. the modding community for this game is still making and updating content which blows my mind since its an older game. just the love and excitement that the community has for total war, especially given the hated and annoying parts of each game lol, just goes to show how great they are. people have guides and videos to help out and tips to getting a bit better at the game, but still boils done to you putting that into action. I started with a few mods, then added more, and then once i got use to the game and started upping the difficulty i was surprised at how i was still surviving on hard and very hard. i thought that perhaps some of the mods were giving me a boost so i actually turned off all the mods that added or changed things other than bug fixes and QOL updates, and was still surprised that i could handle defending, attacking and economic growth really well. Once you have some tactics down, some that are just cheesie yari spear wall (which is super op and fun to use when youre out numbered or anytime that is) and know how some units work and act under the ai it gets down to how you form, order and move your armies and individual units that determines your wins. Some times you can be out numbered 3 to 1 and still survive and even win by playing the battlefield and game mechanics right (doing things that impact morale is a good way to get through regardless of being outnumbered.) I've only ever played as Oda Nobunaga, because he is my favorite (Drifters the anime was when i first learned about him and his character design and personality i thought were great in that show, also i know that its not historically accurate but still). But the other clans have some cool things to change up your tactics with with bonuses or extra things in one area that another may not have. Anyways, its a fun game and can feel complicated to learn all the features and battle mechanics but its so much fun and definitely rewarding once you have those down and wipe out an army that outnumbers you by alot. ENJOY!

***IF YOU NEVER PLAYED A TOTAL WAR GAME, READ THIS FIRST***

If you are a fan of history, and you love the medieval Japan era (samurais and all that), AND you also are looking for a game that kind of tries to be a sort of battle simulator, where you can make your historical army, recreate battles, feel like you are a real general of the era, then i do dare say that TOTAL WAR games might be for you. Total war games mix turn-base strategy campaign maps with real-time strategy in the battles that will decide the fate of your kingdom.  But is SHOGUN for you? probably. I always tell people to choose a total war based on your favourite time-period in history. But it's not necessary to be a samurai enthusiast to enjoy this game

**MAIN REVIEW**

Having played almost all total war games except for the Warhammer series, thrones of britannia and Three kingdoms, I can safely say that this is the total war game with which i had the best overall experience.

The game has 3 different campaigns but for the sake of the review i'll focus on the base Shogun 2 campaign: 
You get to play as one of the main 10(?) clans of Japan's medieval Civil war - Sengoku Jidai. Each clan has a speciality but every faction shares roughly the same roster of units and technology, barring unique features. In the campaign you will have to try and make good armies to take over other clans, make alliances and trade deals, and also develop your provinces to sustain your war effort to become the new shogun. you will fight both on Land and Sea, you can choose to do the battle yourself or let the AI auto-resolve the conflicts. The game even introduces a mechanic to stop the snowball effect that is present in previous total war games with the Realm Divide event where once you become too strong, all clans gang up on you and you have to fight for survival, you either conquer all or die trying.

Battles in this game, even after so many years are still some of the most beautiful. Graphics are great and battles feel well balanced. Contrary to most total war games. every faction shares almost the same exact roster of units, and then every faction will have 1 or 2 or 3 unique units, and it makes a lot of sense thematically because this game is about a japanese civil war, makes sense that clans share the same technology. you need to be smart about your army composition. units kind of work in a rock-paper-scissors system so always pick your fights within fights carefully. battles in this game are really fun because they can get really intense. There's a good deal of skill expression in them. You truly feel like a real general playing this game.

Not much else to add. this game has been always a joy to come back to. it's not perfect, but it's great and probably the best one in my books. 9/10

A Japanese shogun is looking for a new samurai.
He summons three swordsmen, one of them Jewish, to his palace to showcase their skills. The first swordsman stands before the shogun with a sword and a small box. When he opens the box, a small box. When he opens the box, a fly flies out. With one swing of his sword, the fly is dead. The second swordsman again brings a sword and a small box. When he opens the box, an even smaller fly comes out, and he kills it with one swing. The shogun is impressed. At last, the Jewish swordsman walks up. He is also carrying a sword and a small box. He opens the box and an even smaller fly comes out. He swings his sword around many times, but it doesn't seem to affect the fly. "I am disappointed," says the shogun. "You didn't kill the fly." The Jew replies, "A circumcision is not meant to kill."

Its a good game overall, I really liked battles, everything about them is great, could play them for days. Even naval battles are pretty fun. 

There are few things I didn't like about the rest of the game.

It feels like its build as "against the player" game, rather than a game where rules are the same for everybody, for example, if you reach certain level of power other clans will go against you, but if they reach that level of power first, others wont go against them.

This "all against one" thing also added bigger accent on diplomacy wich i think is pretty lame in general, but even more when you keep in mind that total war AI, at least when it comes to diplomacy, is pretty bad.

Agents are also too powerful for my taste, not too OP tho, but still far more powerful than in previous total war games. 

All in all, i liked it and would happily play it again in the future.

My favorite Total War game, and a solid contender for best TW-title up there with Medieval 2 and Rome. Unlike later titles, you can tell that this game was made with love and care, having small, but ultimately meaningful features such as family trees & agent cutscenes. features that has generally been scrapped in later games, possibly deemed to be unnecessary for the core gameplay loop, but if you ask me, they add a great deal of immersion. 
On the topic of the core gameplay loop; we have the battles. So are they good in this game? Yes. Never in total war's history has the battles of the game been more balanced, and about tactics rather than unit stats and special abilities, than they are in this game. Each clan have their strengths and weaknesses, but largely speaking their army rosters are almost the same, which might sound slightly boring, but actually creates a ton of balance to the battles, as they become more about how well you use your tropps than what troops have the biggest [strike] shlongs [/strike] err stats. 
All of this will only begin to scratch the surface, I haven't gone into the economics of the game which are a lot of fun too, or how it just might have the most beautiful art style of any TW game to date. 

So yeah if you like Total War and haven't tried this one yet, go for it, it's absolutely one of the best ones, and also it's DLC policy is nowhere near as atrocious as the later titles even if you still have to pay for blood effects... come on CA stop the greed please.

Originally released in 2011!!!! This strategy game has everything you could really want. It's immersive and thorough. It comes with an encyclopedia which you can access online as well as in game. 
The game offers reenactment of actual historic battles where are you the player can be one of the participants in the battle. 
It's a challenging game you must pay attention to details, timing, money, characters, various clan politics. 
Personally, what I like most is the many moving parts. It is a multidimensional game. 
Your Daimyo’s actions and that of your General’s are monitored by the AI, resulting in other clans pinion of your Daimyo and your Clan, impacting your potential relationships or trade agreements.

07/03/22 Edit: 

(Positive Review)
The game seems to be working much better on 1440p monitors now and the Ui doesn't completely bug out on you, they must have fixed it finally. Much better now and worth a purchase. The blood DLC is still a disgrace but if you grab the whole collection on sale it might not be so bad. One of the better if not the best total war games , we shall see how Warhammer 3 ends up in a couple years. I'll leave the negative past review up so you can see how bad the game was and how pissed off I was at the game previously. At least the game works now, only thing that is missing is a screen lock button for your cursor. You will have to use a separate program for that, try "dual monitor tools". Alt tab and activate it then re-tab back into the game and it should stop it moving onto other monitors if you have any extra screens. 

Try it out and enjoy.

Previous Review:

(Negative Review)
You need a million fixes to get this working these days, and I can barely get it fully functional at all. I had to; Use a screen resolution fix program, a mouse cursor lock program, had to go into the scripts and turn off screen resizing ( if you don't it becomes misaligned on windowed fullscreen). I then found out the ui scale is too large and is cut off on the bottom of the screen and there is no way of resizing it on a 2550 x 1440p monitor, so I don't understand why they have a windowed fullscreen mode if it doesn't work.
Honestly this is a disgrace for a game in 2019, I understand its an older game but I shouldn't have to work this hard for a game on a professional store front. If you aren't prepared to support the game so it at least works on modern hardware, take it off the store front. They are happy to take your money though, of course they are lol. Look at all the bullshit DLC you need for the game too. The fact that they still have the audacity to sell you "blood effects" for £2.50 is absolutely shameful and they still do it in newer titles too. 

If you report these problems on CA forums you are met with bullshit "we know" responses but never any fixes years later. There is nothing worse than patronising non answers, they obviously think customers are brain dead and beyond stupid. There's nothing more insulting. 
If you really want to try this game make sure you either play it on a 1080p monitor, or play it on fullscreen mode on a higher resolution. Playing on windowed fullscreen you will need to do a million fixes, and its not worth the trouble in my opinion, and it's all for nothing if you own any screen higher than 1080p. The UI doesn't scale well and it will have to look like total dog shit, so you can see all the ui elements.
 If you want to pick this up, for the love of god buy it on a 75% off summer sale or something, I can't stress that enough. It's titles like this make me regret supporting games altogether, the shear contempt they have for their own customers is a fucking joke. Just fix the game so I can play it properly and have positive things to say about it.

[b] Still to this day one of the best TW games. [/b]

[b] General stuff : [/b] Singleplayer campaigns are fun, not stale and the AI provides somewhat of a challenge. 
Historical battles are also nice and there is just enough of them. 
The naval battles are not as good and you will most likely find yourself skiping them or just ignoring them in general (except the bonus trade points on the edges of map)
Units seem ballanced and you can make use of all... (but in general ashigaru units are very srong for their cost... and hero unis are not as good as one would think... ye and also light cav can 1 vs 1  generals pretty easily)

[b] Style: [/b] It is a 2011 game and still looks really good, the style of the game and UI is just brilliant. Soundtrack is great.

[b] DLC: [/b] So you just need the [i] Sengoku Jidai Unit Pack [/i] to have the best experince, the ohers are not really necessary but most of them are nice addition (clan DLCs, more units DLCs) and [i] The rise of he samurai campaign DLC [/i] (not that good).
[i] The FALL of the samirai [/i] is now a "sandalone game" but it really is just a great expansion to the base game and i can recomend it, just a nice breath of fresh air and great gameplay.
But c'mon CA do you really have to chrge extra 2,99 € for the [i] Blood pack DLC [/i] ... stuff like this shold be in the base game

[b] Overall Great AI, nice graphics and style, cool units and  fun campaigns
8/10 Ashigaru recomends [/b]

One of my favorite strategy games on steam, hands down. I have never been great at the multitasking required of real time strategy games, so the hybrid system employed in the Total War games works wonders for me. Grand strategy is handled in turns, and only individual battles are real time. I think this allows for a greater layer of strategic thinking while still allowing one to flex their tactical muscles. The theming of this game is wonderful too, the art and music really do wonders to immerse you in the era, even if it isn’t completely historically accurate. Fantastic game.

7. I still do not understand navy battles. 3 Total War Games in where Navy is present and I am still completely lost here.
8. The AI General spam is honestly stupid at times. Fighting an army that has Five "Three star generals" Embedded is an absolute joke

This review rates this game as of 2022, Focused on the "Shogun 2 Campaign mode".

PROS
>Graphics 6.5/10, the over-world (map) is quite dated and the textures in-battle are dated. The UI's custom generals/troops/buildings icons are works of art.

>Gameplay 9.5/10, the opposite of "dumb'd down" Shogun 2 is in-depth having many ways to beat your opponent. Battle (Land/Sea), Diplomacy, Ninjas (Assassinate/Sabotage), Monks (Revolts/Rebels), Metsuke (Bribes/Anti Ninja). Role-play, Min-max, play the game how you want.

>Sound 9/10, Immersive, mostly drums and "old" sounding wood/wind instruments for the music. The guns/cannons have a satisfying "Oomphf", battle cries and sound effects are well made.

>Mods 8.5/10, New clans, in-game balance tweaks and more! I'm not a heavy mod user and mostly play vanilla, myself I've enjoyed Camera zoom extender, Further/Realistic gun range, and Play every empire (Ashikaga, Shoni, Ito, etc.).

+Good price, value for your money.

CONS
Heavy learning curve (well worth the effort), this may take you a couple hours to get your handle on how to win. You can however learn the gameplay in "steps" since there are many ways to win you can entirely avoid every aspect besides battling the enemy (happy to be proven wrong) until you are comfortable.

The battle AI isn't impressive, its just not that smart. The AI will attack without strategy "throwing" units at you or it will just hold areas without making any moves (defensive battles). You can quickly learn these patterns and win "unwinnable" battles. The campaign AI (over-world/map) is better than expected, The AI understands unit "Rock, Paper, Scissors" and will build to defeat the player. The AI receives inflated income and will rely on a numbers advantage to overcome its battle AI weakness.

Dead multiplayer, the game is old. I don't know if there's a discord or similar for people to find player matches, I've had no luck finding randoms to battle however I only tried twice and waited 30 minutes of queue time.

DLC Blood pack.. really? The animations are not worth paying for.

SUMMARY, 33.5/40 (84%)

I enjoyed each hour of this game and I will recommend my friends to purchase. My favourite part of the game is replaying the first 50 or so turns to see how efficient of a start I can make because I prefer smaller battles and low micro management.

The perfect blossom is a rare thing. You could spend your life looking for one, and it would not be a wasted life.

There's nothing quite like watching the ai send an army of yari and katana samurai against your line of guns and cannons. Just set your troops to hold fire until the enemy are real close and then just click the fire at will button and tada, all the enemy are either dead or fleeing.

It has extreme re-play-ability. It just doesn't get dated. I find it to be the best of the Total War franchise.

Shogun 2 is simply an extremely refined and polished game, personaly only Napoleon and Age of Charlemagne(Attila expansion) come sightly close in my eyes. 
One of the few Total War games that i can trully enjoy without the need of any mods, because of its high level of autenticity and historical accuracy in comparison with other TW tittles. 

- The time period and world zone both feel very refreshing as they barely have been touched by any other game before, even previous Total War games(with exeption of Shogun 1). 

- The art work/UI and music/sound are hands down some of the more immersive and better looking/sounding ones in the whole gaming industry in my opinion. Hell even the graphics still look great so many years after.

- The layout of the campaign map gives the AI a decent fighting chance... almost making it look as if it was competent. 

- The unit composition altough seemingly "samy" for all factions, make balance much less of an issue and still leaves a lot of room for diversity and customization(specially on multiplayer). 

- The inclusion of the RPG leveling system for agents and generals gives agency to the players and adds replayability.

- The Avatar Conquest multiplayer it's incredibly engaging and immersive giving each player an unprecedent level customization and personalization over his general, individual units and basicaly the whole army.

There is more to be said, but i think you get the idea... Shogun 2 does a lot of things very well and has an special charm that most Total War games(specially recent ones) fail to capture.

No game is not without flaws tho... most can be found in the multiplayer part of the game; i go over it's biggest flaws here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/34330/discussions/0/1734339624798656380/?ctp=2#c1735468693692217920

This is, by far, the BEST starter for anyone getting into Total War. Not horrible clans, amazing DLC's, not to easy and not too hard, absolutely beautiful, great art, really just the perfect Total War game. This game is the most well-rounded when I say perfect. Example, Total War: War Hammer I, II, and III may be too overwhelming for some or too cinematic. The older games (which are great) may also seem out of date and bad. Three Kingdoms also maybe suffer the same that War Hammer has, however it does have great diplomacy and somewhat good recruiting system. Shogun 2 makes tech research pretty easy, events with more importance, strengths and weaknesses of soldiers, and (somewhat) balanced warfare. Honestly, anyone wanting to get into the community should get this game. This is, by a landslide, one of the best Total War games.

This game is amazing.

I have played Medieval Two total war and enjoyed that so decided to give this a go since a friend of mine recommended it and I had somewhat knowledge of how total war worked.

But wow this game is such a unique experiance and I consider it one of my favourite games at the moment. At first I was finding it a hard to learn at first but you get good help from the tutorials and what you should expect the first time you do a battle or campaign.

The battles are amazing. Whilst requiring good concentration and skill to manage armies: you cannot help see the amazing detail and animations of each soldier murdering and charging into each other. It truly is beautiful chaos to watch.

The campaigns are excellent as well. Aspects such as realm divide and European traders keeps the experience unique and hard. I love each of the unique aspects of the factions and how each resource such as gold and blacksmiths are priority and you have to make tough decision on what province to capture next. Also the AI aren't stupid.

Overall, get this game. I think it is a very unique experiance and fantastic game. I'd truly say this is worth the time and investment.

I bought Total war Shogun 2 on the 27th of January 2019 which means in 5 days i will have owned it for 3 years i have put 163.4 hours into this game at the time of writing this review. I would say this game has been one of the biggest influences in my gaming career which really only started on pc in 2018. Shogun 2 has lead me to the RTS genre and the RTS community this has lead to multiple friendships and i give all of the credit to this game i first came to owning this game when my brother told me to get it so we could play together (which he used to just kick my ass for fun) but even with getting my butt kicked by my brother because he was better at strategy than i was i still have fond memories of me suicidal y throwing my men into an out numbering force just for the thrill of battle for me at that time it wasn't about winning it was learning what worked and what didn't which i would say ive gotten pretty bloody good at i thank this game for all of its wonderful features and time i rate this game a 9/10 for me. i would very much recommend this game to anyone who either likes RTS games or likes the samurai period.

One of the best of the Total War games.  I have always been a fan of the firearm era in their games so Shogun 2, Napoleon, Empire are my favourites.  Now Total War Victoria or Civil War... I would love.  This game has been around for quite a while and I reinstall it when I get the need to run down my enemy with my cavalry.  The Japanese map is nice, the research aspects and character customization is well designed.  Combat is fun with the usual warning that you don't advance any troops through your cannons because the heartless crew will just blow away our guys.  

Sea battles are fun and improved over earlier Total War games, still a bit slow but hey, it's the early age of steam.  Maybe "Hollywood Tom" adviser would be a nice add on.  

All of this to say, if the price is right, grab this one and watch your hours disappear like they do when playing Civilization!  One more turn!

In my opinion the best Total War game of all (I played quite a few although not all). Several are quite fun. Napoleon was quite similar and good. Rome II was also good and Warhammer. But somehow this one appealed to me most. I haven't played this in years so it's hard to remember exactly what it was. One of the key aspects was the fortification system and the balance between long range and short range units. Arguably one of the best Total War games ever made. Empire Total War got some flack for a poor ai, and Shogun 2 got some flack because CA improved the ai and made the game an actual challenge! If you play it safe and take your time...you will lose because the ai clans will eat up all the land and then you and your two provinces have harder challenge because you’re now at war with a clan with 11 regions and allies. 

One problem with previous Total War games was lack of challenge after the hump, you know, the time when you beat your last major challenger and are now the dominant force on the map and that’s left to do is mop up everyone else. Shogun 2 doesn’t have that with the “realm divide” feature where the Shogun declares war on you and eventually everyone turns against you giving you a fight to survive and fight to win. Did you prepare properly to weather the coming war? If not, you will lose. What a great challenge!

The best base game experience of any Total War game I have played to date. Lot's of fun playing as the different Daimyo's with what I would consider to be some of the best unit balancing you will find in any modern TW game. Unit's don't die too fast, there are unit's that can actually stand up against ranged attacks that AREN'T cavalry. 

The largest criticism I have is Agent spam. I love the concept of agents but the fact that you can basically have 1 of each agent per town you control makes the spam get a little ridiculous. As an example one of the factions starts on an island and it was nearly impossible for me to attack them because as soon as my troops would land via Ships they would be surrounded by assassins, spy's, geisha's, and diplomats all ready to fuck my day up. Obviously you can still brute force your way through all this but you risk losing generals or entire armies if they get successfully bribed.

Love this game.  It's not quite easy to start, but YouTube has lots of great videos if you're a bit unsure of what you're doing beyond the tutorial.  I'm by no means an expert at this game, but if you're like me and enjoy Real Time Strategy AND Turn Based Strategy AND Samurai history, this is as good as it gets until they decide to make #3!!

In my opinion, the best Total War game. Shogun 2 has managed to evoke it's chosen time period better than any of the previous titles in the series. The first positives that stood out to me were the beautiful UI, and the soundtrack. Those are just the beginning - a cool campaign map awaits you, with a weather system, relaxing flute music, and unit cards that are LEGIBLE (and pretty). Plus, classic TW warfare.
The base game is solid on it's own, but I urge you to consider getting some of the DLC. I recommend Fall of the Samurai, which adds a second campaign with all new units and clans, and a shift in the time period. Coupled with that DLC, this game is a 10/10 for me. Before you buy take a gander at the soundtrack on youtube, it's great.
EDIT/UPDATE: It appears Fall of The Samurai was folded into the base game.

As someone who came back after playing TWWH 2 all i can say is, Holy fuck what happened to total war and how they fuck did they strip so much out of the game. I have a shameful amount of hours spent in this game (a huge chunk of it spent running in the background, mind you) and can say with complete confidence that if you decide to buy this game when it's next on sale, you'll also get sucked right in.

Good: The most accessible full-fledged Total War entry out there, easy to learn and difficult to master. TW:S is so fun to learn that it got me hooked onto Total War as a franchise! Great use of setting -- you'll want to read all about the Sengoku Jidai once you get into this game. Fantastic soundtrack that fits right into the setting -- so good that you wouldn't ever suspect it was written by some white guy in Australia! Its expansion, Fall of the Samurai, is a perfectly executed 180 turn from how the base game plays and will again suck you right in for even more hours. 

Funny: The in-game announcer. His cheesy faux-Japanese accent is an unintentionally goofy contrast to the formal-sounding Japanese spoken by your formations of troops. "Our men are running from the battlefield -- a shamefur dispraaaay!" 

Bad: The same mechanics that make TW:S accessible are also responsible for it lacking depth compared to other TWs. Longtime TW players liken TW:S gameplay to a rock-paper-scissors style of combat when played by competent commanders. Also, TW:S's infamous endgame mechanic ("realm divide") was polarizing to the TW fan base in 2011 and remains polarizing to this day for being inelegantly implemented. Mods exist to make the mechanic less... abrupt, shall we say.

Compared to Total War: Napoleon there is more focus on having to build up your cities and your emerging empire, but the battles are still a core component of the game. It was visually impressive for its time and it actually still looks decent today (2021). The interface was the best in the Total War series up to then.

Ten years on it's still the best Total War game made. The campaign map is beautiful, the general's speeches are rousing, and the aide-de-camp is iconic. The unit roster is simple, with meaningful differences between every unit and a battlefield use for all of them. Likewise factions are similar but each have a strong flavour based on their specialisation and location on the map. The agents are impactful, but not spammable as in previous titles, or super human as in some later titles. Some of the boosts the game gives the enemy at higher difficulties can be frustrating, but the sense that your foes have every advantage only sweetens the taste of victory.

The last true strategy game developed by creative assembly, if they applied this games design to today's tools we would have one of the best strategy games on the market. I was able to apply an adaptation of Napoleons strategy of concentrated force across the campaign and tactical map to effectively fight on 2 fronts. Front 1 being the defensive front slowing the enemy in a war of attrition or outright crushing them in a decisive defensive battle opening them for a potential counter attack. Front 2 being the offensive front focusing on isolating enemy armies from their castles defeating them in the field and depending on the situation forcing capitulation through diplomacy or taking the territory for my own. This strategy allows me to defeat enemies on the offensive front who are similar or greater in power. I have found the most success with this strategy playing as the Oda Clan as their cheap high quality levy allow me to tie down and outmaneuver stronger samurai warriors and though each general commands a force smaller than the enemies 20 stack when fighting together they can overwhelm the enemy through sheer force of numbers. You just have to give zero fucks about how many peasants die. As each turn goes by you feel a sense of satisfaction at seeing your faction incrementally grow in power with each victory but the game moves at a pace where as the AI's power scales with your own thus always challenging you to some degree. I would like to note that this experience was not possible without the love, dedication, and skill of the modding community in their efforts to improve on what the developers gave them.
Even though this game has a quite a bit of age, it still plays well and is a fun time!

As a longtime player of the Total War series, Shogun 2 is my new favorite. Going into the game, I was somewhat skeptical, having not previously been interested in the time period, but Shogun 2 quickly won me over. The game is beautiful, both on the tactical and strategic level, and does a phenomenal job of conveying the beauty and danger of the time and place. The soundtrack is outstanding, and I often find myself slowing the game down to half-speed just to watch the gorgeous combat animations.  AI can still be dopey at times but for the most part is greatly improved over previous Total War titles. Even on lower difficulties, the game is quite a challenge. Factions are similar, but different enough that the game has plenty of replay value. I would recommend this game to any fan of the Total War series, or strategy gamers in general.

OK I'm older than the average gamer and have a history of traditional wargaming - map based and figure based games/campaigns. I find all the Total War immersive and an excellent up to date computer based version of traditional wargaming. Shogun 2 is a particular favourite as it was the first one I really started to customise with user based extensions and later my own. Today, I'm downloading it again to play it for the first time in about 3 years and can hardy wait. Programming wise, apart from a few moody extensions the game is very reliable and lock-up and crash free. It also gets a big plus for not stealing all my memory and CPU run time allowing me to multi-task with high end productivity and graphics software.

By far, one of my favorite Total War games in history. The music is amazing, the lore gathered is really awesome and the sieges and combat are among the most fun I’ve had in a long while. Even the “lack” of unit diversity can be easily ignored by how the game plays and each faction encourages certain playstyles based on your starting location and bonuses.

For me, the main downsides of the game are 1) The rise of the Samurai DLC which feels really lackluster, more so because the amount of stacks the enemy can push is astounding and, 2) The general speeches which seem bizarre.

Watching individual units fight, how they move, dodge, counter or even using martial arts in some instances are among the most entertaining things you can do in this game. More so if you slow down the action by half.

Crashes crashes crashes. Zoom into battles? Crash. Try to boot up a naval battle? Crash. Try to play the game? More crashes. On top of that there's countless sound errors that keep popping up as the game seems to become more and more unstable every time I get a new computer. I dearly enjoy Shogun 2 and believe it is one of the best games in the series with FOTS being my all-time favorite entry in Total War. The issue therein lies in the fact that it seems to endlessly become more unstable the more time drifts on and hardware evolves beyond it. 

The battles are tons of fun and the gunfighting is a very unique experience compared to most total war games. The maps are very fun to play with and well designed, and a lot of the mechanics, although straightforward in nature, have massive potential.

The only gameplay problem is the issue with AI agents killing off your entire army and ending the campaign instantly as there is no real way to counter them, even with your own agents at high levels. Even if that wasn't the case it is a horrible mechanic and is entirely luck based.
If I have to quit a campaign and restart because the AI spams a dozen agents that destroy my entire army over the course of a single turn then its just not worth playing the campaign
The fact that one of the primary selling points of the game, the campaign, simply relies on mods to fix the game randomly breaking and becoming unplayable/unwinnable is absurd. 
As of writing this review none of the no-agent mods seem to work with vanilla or overhauls which just adds up to like 30 hours of wasted time getting halfway through the campaign before the AI basically console commands your armies away.

Shogun 2 is one of those games. You just never really get tired of it. It is always welcoming and still looks relatively modern despite its age. Whether you want to have fun with your friends or just spend a quiet night playing by yourself, Shogun 2 has got you covered.

Multiplayer has many options: you can play the campaign with your friends, play competetively in Avatar conquest or just play an all-out slugfest with a group of friends and almost unlimited Koku (the currency in this game) at your disposal.

Single player has you either going to medieval ages and clashing your swords against other upstart clans or going to more modern times, fighting the short and much-forgotten Boshin War where imperial armies clashed against the more traditional forces.

Not many games have this much content to offer. An all of it it deep, balanced and well thought out. I mean, there's even an encyclopedia embedded into the game which offers you not only information on how things work, but also gives historical context of why this is in the game. Now how many games do that these days?

WARNING!!!:
Do not buy this game when your in the middle of your college year unless you want to fail.

A tried and true classic for the Total War series. No matter how much time goes by, I always turn towards Shogun 2. The unit diversity, differences in clans and wide range in play-through make this one of Total War's best. The game is easy to figure out, yet adds in enough complexity to not make it easy. The only major thing I was taken aback by was the ease with which your closest allies turn on you when the Shogunate declares war on you however this is an extremely minor issue compared to the great many things I love about this game. All in all, I would recommend this game to any strategy or Total War lover

Total War is one of my favorite grand strategy franchise. You play one of nine of the major clans during the Sengoku Jidai (Age of War). Starting from 1545, you have to contend for the Shogunate in Kyoto by fighting for territories and securing power while trying to secure trade and alliances. In this game, technology is relatively stale and instead, you focus more on philosophy, either in Bushido or in the Way of Chi. As time progresses, you either fight or conform to Christianity. With certain trade routes, you receive superior resources and possibly muskets. This game presents you with plenty of decisions and is by far, the best Total War I have played so far.

Shogun 2 is one of the best TW titles besides Rome (the original one). Has the most polished and balanced gameplay compared to other TW titles, Each faction has similar units with a few special units between them. Shogun 2 combat heavily leans on rock-paper-scissor type of balance. Nonetheless, the combat is very fun and challenging. 

The art in Shogun 2 is lovely combining Japanese caligraphy and artstyles. Loading screens, unit cards, the UI, etc. are well designed.

The only drawback is some unit pathing, mostly in siege battles, which is present in all TW games tbh.

Overall 8.5/10

The game is fun, and reminds me of what I love about total war. But, I can also see some of the things that made it go down hill, and kind of foreshadowed the things I despise about newer total wars. I do recommend the game for multiplayer battles, and maybe campaign. The campaign is fun, but, instead of making a seemingly smart AI (which is possible), they just made it so the AI doesn't play by your rules. So, in reality, not only is the AI really, genuinely stupid, but, the only way to beat the AI is really throwing your troops into the samurai meat grinder, and other ways that don't always make sense. For instance, pike and shot is a pain in the ass. Don't do it. But, wanna full sprint your guys into a line of arrows or gun fire? Be CA's guest apparently. It feels like many of the tactics in the game are based off of "Me unit more expensive! Me unit charge now!" Which I will get to now actually.
Another thing that's a big pain is the fact that unit experience doesn't seem to matter. In medieval 2, if you upgraded a unit of spear militia or even just town militia to the max, they could be most normal spear sergeants. Get them max experience, max weapon upgrades, and max armour upgrades; they beat any spear sergeants that don't have those upgrades sheerly because of that experience. It makes it seem like experience matters, and there's a reason to not only care about your troops, but, also keep them around. In Shogun 2, like many total war games after it, unit XP doesn't seem to matter. You can recruit a fresh unit of bow samurai with no xp, and they'll beat loan sword or yari ashigaru that have max experience with ease. Yet, these ashigaru, despite being peasants, have won numerous battles. And, four units of them are bested by a bunch of guys who were just given their armour, bows, and swords five minutes ago. It seems like most units win because they're priced higher, and not because they genuinely have battle experience. It's the problem I have with Rome 2, and many other total war game. Not matter how experienced a unit gets, it will never best any unit that's higher priced than it. And, that to me takes away from the good of the game.
However, in some cases there are reasons to care about your troops. They cost A LOT of money, even if the game says you'll get them cheaper. Food does seem to be a problem, but, only because it doesn't let you upgrade. If you have the money, feel free to not feed your troops. But, the AI doesn't have this problem. So, if you can't upgrade, guess what? They will. Because the AI wasn't given an economy. 
The battles do feel nice, and very visceral when you do fight them. Even though tactics in the game don't fully make sense, it's still enjoyable to watch. Especially if you're the type of person who just spams out people waves. Because, if you can get the money to do it, it will work. The game's moral system seems to not like troops being outnumbered. So, even if that unit of bow samurai can take out four units of maxed out yari ashigaru by itself, if you have four armies worth of them, that doesn't matter. And, that to be is both a big problem, but, is also perfectly balanced, and not exploitable at all.
The game is genuinely fun, and it feels so good. But, it goes from rock, paper, scissors mechanics to, "My rock shinier than your rock. My rock win. Ogga Booga." And, it does this very quickly. You cannot rely on the peasant wall tactic, even if your peasant wall has all maxed out XP. Because, it will still die unless you have three other armies supporting said peasant wall. And, that's both a good, and bad thing. 

Now for a not so lengthy conclusion:
The game is fun. And, I do recommend you play it. I did say a lot of bad about it, but, it's still a decent total war game. But, be warned of the things I've talked about, or it will ruin the game for you. It really sincerely will.

I woke up this morning with a bad hangover, and my penis was missing again. This happens all the time–it’s detachable. This comes in handy a lot of the time. I can leave it home when I think it’s gonna get me in trouble, or I can rent it out when I don’t need it. But now and then I go to a party, get drunk, and the next morning I can’t for the life of me remember what I did with it. First I looked around my apartment, and I couldn’t find it. So I called up the place where the party was; they hadn’t seen it either
I asked them to check the medicine cabinet, ‘cause for some reason I leave it there sometimes, but not this time
So, I told them if it pops up to let me know. I called a few people who were at the party, but they were no help either
I was starting to get desperate. I really don’t like being without my penis for too long; it makes me feel like less of a man, and I really hate having to sit down every time I take a leak. After a few hours of searching the house and calling everyone I could think of, I was starting to get very depressed. So I went to the Kiev, and ate breakfast. Then, as I walked down Second Avenue towards St. Mark’s Place, where all those people sell used books and other junk on the street, I saw my penis lying on a blanket next to a broken toaster oven. Some guy was selling it–I had to buy it off him. He wanted twenty-two bucks, but I talked him down to seventeen. I took it home, washed it off and put it back on. I was happy again. Complete.

People sometimes tell me I should get it permanently attached, but I don’t know–even though sometimes it’s a pain in the ass, I like having a detachable penis.

tl;dr :  very good game and i have a detachable penis : D

Total War: SHOGUN 2 is absolutely amazing, I've never been so touched over a strategy game despite my lack of interest in them. Shogun 2 strikes the balance between arcade and realism. You do not have to think like a sweaty HOI4 player to run your clan.  (sorry hoi4 players out there your game is still ok)

NOTE: DON'T BUY FALL OF THE SAMURAI FIRST.
I see some people having problems with FoTS, it is a standalone game but you need the original shogun 2 to launch it because it is deemed as a DLC. If you bought FoTS first, steam will not allow you to buy acquire shogun 2 as they think that you already have it (?) That's what i saw in the reviews anyways so be mindful.

The battles.
This is where Shogun 2 REALLY shines. To keep it simple, it's like a card game where specific units beats specific units while it being vulnerable to yet another specific units.
For example; The Yari (spear) units are vulnerable to Katana units, Katana units are vulnerable to Cavalry units, and Cavalry units are vulnerable to Yari units.
But of course, there are WAY MORE units out there with their specific role, combine the perfect army composition and make full use of the terrain around the battlefield. Be it a castle, river, bridge or maybe just a single hill will change the tide of battle.

The Campaign 
Now this is the part where it falls slightly. The Campaign feels slightly a bit bland after a few campaign runs. I've played as the Shimazu, Oda, Takeda and the Date. Currently trying the Uesugi. While the politics system is indeed good, using a "relationship points" sort of way, 
"It's like every clan you first meet wants you dead" -The Shogunate

Politics in shogun 2 can be a bit tiring, especially after the realm divide. It's a system where your clan has overtaken the Shogunate, or is deemed the enemy of the state by the Shogun. You think your vassals and long time Allies will support you in this glorious Campaign of Japan? No. They turn their backs on you.. and it hurts :(.    
Though after you became Shogun, that is to take Kyoto for a whole year (4 turns/seasons) All your NEWLY made vassals will not turn their backs on you.

And to top the Cons off, the game is VERY mod-able. 

This completely negates all the bad things in this game, except for a few bugs which imo doesn't have a huge impact.

The DLC.
The DLC is fun I suppose, such as the Clan packs having special traits to them. The Sengoku Jidai pack and the saints and heroes DLC just adds a couple of new units, but it will definitely improve the fun for sure.
Now the blood pack, kiss my A##. Do you really need to spend money to add things like BLOOD and decapitation?

I mean it's up to you really, but it still boggles me on why would you need to spend money for blood... I suppose wait for a sale? It's up to you.

To sum it up, I absolutely recommend shogun 2 to you, it has pulled me into an interest in learning more about Japan's history, it's very enjoyable both in an Arcady way and a Semi-Realistic way. Though if you don't like strategy game like I do, maybe you won't like it that much but I personally do. I'd give this game a solid 9/10.

Simply put...make one mistake and hours of work were for not.

If you feel like you need to punish yourself or you want a challenge, than go ahead and buy it.

If you decide to play this game, here are a number of tips:

- SAVE OFTEN (pretty much before EVERY decision i mean EVERY decision)
- WATCH YOUR GLOBAL FOOD LEVEL (if you mess that up you'll most likely have to start over)
- BUILD A STRONG NAVY (if you want it or not, it is necessary to secure key strategic points and not get 
  invaded...yes INVADED)
- WATCH YOUR GENERALS LOYALTY (if it drops to 1 disband him!)
- YOU WILL PLAY MOST OF THE GAME ON THE CAMPAIGN MAP (get used to it)

And lastly:
- S A V E  O F T E N  !!!!111

The game still sucks mostly (crashes here and there) and it WILL NOT take you by the hand.
Meaning the strategy map tutorials are useless and you'll have to learn everything that is important on your own. Now this can be fun, if that is what you are looking for. However i am sick and tired of the fact that SW-DEVs (and producers) 1.) do not seem to understand simple UI-design guidelines and 2.) seemingly have no structure throughout their feature designs (i.e.  1.) simple popup messages if you save 2.) no popup or confirm message if you are moving your pawns around). The number of times i had to reload because the pawn was running in the wrong direction or i did not know a certain feature, that when triggered completely messes up your game to the point where you have no choice BUT to restart.

And the list goes on...

@DEVs: Add tutorials for the part of the game the player actually spends most of their time with i.e. the campaign map.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#1 out of 500+)... it's time for Total War: Shogun 2

I kind of hate Shogun 2. I've been playing Total War games since the demo disc for the first Shogun in PC Gamer, way back when--I fell in love immediately. And Shogun 2 is, arguably, the very best entry in the franchise. It's good. Really, really good. Phenomenally good. And the Fall of the Samurai expansion allows us to experience the surprisingly-engaging gunpowder-age combat introduced in Empire, while still retaining the fantastic traditional medieval combat in the base game. 

Don't get me wrong, it's not perfect--naval combat is a bit of a mess, diplomacy is as wonky as ever, and the lack of the throne room or any similar roleplay-style systems is a bit disappointing. But it's still one of the best strategy games out there--nevermind among the best looking.

But, see, Shogun 2 isn't simply the best Total War game out there--it's also the last good Total War game out there. It's the one game by which every subsequent Total War is judged, and they invariably fall far, far, far short. It's really depressing, honestly. I'm sitting here, writing this, desperately hoping the upcoming Three Kingdoms will finally buck this trend (after all, Shogun 2's brilliance came after Empire's catastrophe) but I am not optimistic.
Not a Shamefulru Dispray.

Shogun II, with the exception of some clan abilities and unique resources, offers a more symmetrical experience than the modern Total War games. That said, if you don't mind that, this is one of the most balanced games in the series, and it is dripping in atmosphere. The speeches you hear from your generals before a battle ever fail to hype you up. By the time the end game comes around, the AI will be more of a threat to you than it is in other Total War games. That's because if you are on a path to victory, by becoming and remaining Shogun, they will all declare war on you. Of course, by that time, you should be the dominant clan in Japan, but this mechanic ensures that an entire playthrough is interesting, rather than becoming a complete cakewalk in the endgame. Units may move a little slower in this game than in recent Total War games, but an upside to that is you will have a greater degree of control over your units on the battlefield.
The battle gameplay is off the hook amazing!

Total War: Shogun 2 is a beautiful grand strategy/real-time strategy game that continues to be fun even a decade after its release. If you love anything about feudal Japan, this is a must-have.[list][/list][b]Great[/b][list][*]Great variety of combat scenarios means weather, terrain, season and individual unit stats really make a difference.[*]Enemy AI provides a challenge regardless of what difficulty level you choose.[*]Visuals are quite beautiful and feel very immersive.[*]Great sound design and soundtrack.[*]Huge mod community that is still active. There is a mod for everything- changing units, adding more clans, longer campaigns, different maps, etc.[*]DLCs are a good value and the two major expansions (Rise of the Samurai and Fall of the Samurai) add a lot of replayability.[/list][b]Not so great[/b][list][*]Multiplayer is dead at this point, but honestly that's not a huge loss since the campaign is where the replayability is at.[*]If you have a potato PC, the battles may be laggy since it's rendering every unit and its behavior individually (especially when you zoom in to the max).[/list]
Strategy without tactics is the slowest route to victory. Tactics without strategy is the noise before defeat. The enlightened ruler is heedful, and the good general is full of caution.

This game is a fine work of art, almost perfectly balanced (yari ashigaru) and once you get the hang of it, the game becomes insanely fun! 

Go buy it.

Pros
The game itself is very good. Swords and guns require a fair amount of manuvering, and one wrong click can mean you lose like 50/200 soldiers just instantly to a hail of gunfire. Cannons have a huge range, and could be OP, but are fun to shoot from 1st person.

Cons
Straight melee can be useless when fighting entrenched gunners. Sword units can be pretty much obsolete, since you can just rotate gunner units until victory. Honestly a battle can feel like a lot of skirmishs, a lot of sitting, watching bullets fly, moving, and repeating. There isn't very often the super satisfying charge of melee or horse units into each other, that you get in other games.

BIGGEST CON
This game is super buggy. For the record, I play on an early 2015 Macbook Air, which is listed to work. However, any time I exit full screen I get the tutorial book open with no way to close. Any time a screen time notification comes up, the game freezes. Ordering units around usually has to be done 1 at a time, since group positioning of lots of units at once leads to some unusual decisions.One could think of this as untrained soldiers not following orders, but often each set of commands I give, requires a full pause, me ordering each unit individually, and pausing every 30 seconds to repeat.

A lot of this wouldn't matter if you could save during battles. However, the historical battles are like an hour long on all normal speed, and more often than not, it's the AI making it's own decisions, and my units die of incompetence. That leads to having to start the whol battle over again.

Overall, I think this is a fun game, but you need way better hardware, and very good micro control.

20 hr update: If you get the frozen tutorial book open, do the three fingers up, to move the program to a new desktop, with the frozen tutorial windows somewhere else. The top inch of your screen is cut off, but at least you can finish the level.

57 hr update: Beat short campaign. Fun game. Needs above workarounds to be functional, but once you have that, it's nice.

Many will fight me but this was Total War at it's peak of design. Game play is beautifully simplistic, but is far from dull. Units have clear roles and there is no bloating of 12 different spears infantry. The campaign is straight forward, making your goals clear.

Some will tell me that this game is [i]too[/i] simple. And I disagree. Why? This game at it's heart is a a look back at what started this franchise, and making it as best as it can be with what was available at the time.

What more, this title easily has the best expansion: Fall of The Samurai (Technically it's own game now) which I can best describe as probably the best line warfare I have played in a game. If you are looking to get into TW, start here. You won't regret it.

Shogun is one of those games which you'll throw an entire weekend away on a major campaign, only to feel a little lost after once you've finished it. With immersive micro gameplay and a grand strategy (that is full but not complete in the way Civilisation is), there's nothing quite like watching 1000 soldiers smash into 1000 other soldiers. In a way, I'd say it's cathartic.

It's worth watching some YouTube videos to truly master the game. The tutorials only guide you on how to move units around the battlefield, but you won't learn battlefield tactics like "Hammer and Anvil" or "Bait and Switch" unless you take the time to study it a little. 

Definitely considering the Fall of Samurai DLC - I'm in the mood to blast soldiers away with cannons now.

Battle maps are a thrill with thousands of units and mechanics to learn and utilise to minute casualties and ensure victory - winning an uphill battle is fantastic feeling.

Suffice to say there’s a lot of content here, and definitely worth the price even just for single player.

For Total War veterans, Shogun 2 is by far one of the most slick and well made of the entire franchise. If you enjoy the series this one is a no brainer. If you're looking for a TW experience in Japan, you wont find a better game.

For those who are new to Total War games, this is a great place to start. Shogun 2 built on many of the issues in the previous games and as always does well staying true to its historical routes. 

If there were any negatives I'd point out its that if you're looking for a lot of variety you wont find it here. The factions have many differences but after a while it can be a tad samey. If you love Samurai, it's not a problem but if you enjoy matching up widely different armies to see how things play out then you're going to be a tad disappointed.

My most played total war game. Mostly because I'm a weeb. It isn't flawless. There isn't squalor and fertility yet. So farm only depends on how much plain area a province have. And market consumes food instead of creates squalor. And in FoTS it's simply generates money and modernize the faction. There's not enough unique traits and or units to actually change your strategy in campaign. And AI not taking advantage of clan strength or trying to be the first clan with gunpowder or monk units doesn't help either.

The multiplayer avatar is a nice touch. Realm divide is something that is unique to this game that keeps it interesting. Trying out converting to christian is always fun.  Despite its age it's beautiful looking still. And FoTS was such a refresh, there's mix of the old and modern units, naval bombardments, train tracks, gatling gun, torpedo boats and ironclads.

All in all, I'll be waiting for the next shogun, empire, and medieval. With at least the similar campaign system to Rome II and Attila while keeping the events. I like Shogun 2 for it's uniqueness, but it's old and less polished as the later total war.

For a game that is fixated on battles there isnt much expression in land battles. You just find a troop setup and pretty much use that throughout your whole campaign. But the biggest problem I faced is not being able to properly setup a defense in your castle because you don't know which direction the enemy is coming from even though that should be a given since theyre coming onto your land. The naval battles are terrible and the enemy will move their units to the edge of the map while staying inside the boundaries so you are forced to waste your time and hunt them down. Monks are kind OP, having 3-4 rebel clans appear amidst the middle of your territory while in a war with every other clan is literally unplayable and doesnt really make much sense that monks have that power unless theyre literally god. Other than that the game is still good because of historical accuracy but not sure how people can play the game so much with so little micro actions in the game, feels too repetitive to me. The game is enjoyable because it takes place in Japan so the experience cant be replicated anywhere else.

[h1]Buy Shogun 2 with Steam seasonal sale to get a decent discount[/h1]

[b]Shogun 2 focuses on 16th century when firearm was firstly introduced to Japan during Sengoku period[/b]

Compared to the RTS game I've played before (e.g., Age of Empires), Shogun 2 is a great mixture of both business simulation and large scale, real-time field battle. You not only have to focus on military reinforcement, but also economical & technological improvement. Most importantly, what truly attracts me is its Ukiyo-e art image design, which gives me a strong feeling about Japanese culture.

Give it a shot if you're interested in the elements mentioned above.

They somehow left out the element of fun.

I was excited to see rifles being used in a strategy game like this, but their range is so short that it looks like they wanted to nerf them for balancing to keep melee and bow units relevant, but that just defeats the purpose of even including rifles. The animations for the riflemen is missing, and the sounds of the rifles firing is awful, with one of the sounds being the same as the M1 Carbine from Day of Defeat.

There's other missing or unfinished animations throughout the game, as if they gave up at some point, yet still wanted to try to sell a bunch of DLC which is advertised on the menu. The riflemen shoot too far to the sides of a regiment because they're all aiming for the enemy soldier right at the ends of the line. Sometimes Gatling cannons show an animation of firing when ordered to, but they don't fire - I've only been able to get half of them to fire, and the ones that do fire don't need reloading.

There's features that seemed more annoying than fun, like camera shake that can't be disabled, an attrition mechanic where your soldiers instantly start dying when away from home. Apparently units can change sides, although I didn't enjoy playing long enough to see it, it sounds like it defeats the point of strategy games if your units just join the enemy.

The program doesn't want to minimise. From a battle you can't get to the main menu, and the menu is very graphically intense and takes ages to load, so it's annoying having to finish every battle and then have to wait for the menu to load each time. The historical battles and naval battles left a poor impression. The campaign map honestly looks like trash. Campaign missions distract from the gameplay and make little sense.

You can't stop a friendly unit from joining a battle as reinforcements. Campaign tips have to be closed by clicking a button, but moving the mouse to it moves the camera away from Japan, making a lot of early gameplay more frustrating than it needs to be. The savegames are hidden away in C:\Users\name\AppData\Roaming\The Creative Assembly\Shogun2\save_games

Trying the campaign on easy, and the enemy units were so overpowered that it's basically lost in the first turn - campaigns are supposed to go on for about 150 turns. Sieges are dull, units can barely move within fortifications, and a lack of siege weapons makes them unbearable.

After logging 1,000 hours in [i]Empire[/i] I thought this would improve on it, but it just felt like a bad mod that remains expensive a decade later at £24.99 and another £31.92 for the DLC. It still lacks a lot of animations, and rather than fix it (or even fix the memory leak in [i]Empire[/i]) they just kept making shallow DLC.

Honestly the best total war game. This was the peak of the franchise.

In its vanilla state, Shogun 2 is a solid game. Mechanics are fairly tight, graphics are pretty, and battles feel fairly well balanced even on legendary which is what I typically play. However, it lacks robust siege battles and unit diversity. One of the things I think this game has going for it is that all factions will more or less have the same units available to them, which means more emphasis is put on tactics and strategy. With mods like expanded japan, new units, and fortresses of the samurai, it feels like a whole new game. Beautiful fort layouts make for interesting and far more involved siege battles. New unit types add diversity and new cost/benefit analyses to recruitment that the AI also makes full use of. Expanded Japan adds dozens of new clans and provinces, and it doesn't make the campaign map feel cluttered or like it balloons the difficulty. On legendary difficulty, with the total mod package, it is a tense and rewarding experience. Your moves need to be planned carefully, and you can't rely on simply having better troops than your enemies. In fact you will often need to win with inferior soldiers. Expanding without leaving yourself open feels like playing a game of chess. The mid and late games don't fall off like they do for me in other TW games. Shogun 2 will keep you strategically and tactically engaged from start to finish.

Total War: Shogun 2 shares in the ranks of "classic" Total War games. I have played every Total War entry and firmly believe it outclasses many of the more-recent entries in the series. The game's mechanics boast a  seamless blend and transition between traditional Japanese combat and the imperialist-influenced modern combat while at the same time maintaining a more simple grand strategy interface. If you are a fan of "Napoleon" and "Medieval 2", this entry is for you.

My first and favorite Total War. I would like it to be a bit more historically accurate but that can be achived, along with other improvements, with mods available on Steam Workshop.

Shogun 2 is an interesting game. It suffers from alot of the flaws that the warscape engine introduced into the series but it makes the most of what it has. 
Melee is as in most of these games kina shit, the charges are good but as soon as the actual melee starts it devolves into blobs that resolve everything through kill moves, there is an invisible dice roll and then one of the infantry models either dies or plays a fancy draw animation. The animations themselves are good but its so tedious to have to sit through what is essencially a shit load of auto resolves. Units cannot gang up on a single target its all duels unless you are charging. Of course you can skewer these stats and can tip the balance of said duels on your side by outnumbering, exausting and outflaking the enemy and its still nowhere near as bad as empire or rome 2 was so that is at least a big plus. Its a bad system but its the best version of said bad system
Ranged combat. Now here we have the best part of the warscape engine, Bullets fly fast and hit hard, all the gun sound effects are flaccid but the bullets and impact sounds are good. If you pause the game you can see each individual projectile as they fly though the air and when that son of a bitch lands it can stop anyone dead in his tracks. Arrows and artillery are also the best they have been in the total war series, there is something magical about watching your men pull back those bow strings and bury entire infantry lines under  a hail of arrows. You get to really feel the force of those arrows when they bury themselves in whatever poor son of a bitch happens to be on the other side, shame japs never got behind the concept of shields.
Cav, unline the old games they lack the mass they used to have and they also blob rather hard but the devs have gone into great lengths to lessen those problems, when you create a wedge as an example your men will actually divide entire units in two and after they split them up start moping them up and chop them to bits while they are in dissaray, there is still no unit collision but they fake it quite well.
Navy. I dont have much to say as i tend to avoid naval combat in all its forms and all the games that has boats but its surprisingly enjoyable, from shogun 2 to fall of the samurai naval combat is not that bad. Shogun 2 rewards micro management and positioning because when your men are still stuck with bows and matchlocks your angle of attack can be the difference between a lot of wasted arrows and alot of enemy dead crew men. In fall of the samurai micro still matters as a good co-ordinated broadside that punches through the hull of a steamboat has a big change to cause a huge explosion as the ammo goes off killing everything around it, Good fucking stuff.
Diplomacy, Its as good as its going to get for a total war game, you can do fancy stuff like arranged marriages between houses, you can create alliances that will last for more than 5 rounds and force others to break alliances with their neigbours so you can double team them, you can forcefully spread your ideology/ religion in your neighbours to make them easier to conquer in the future and the AI unlike empire kina makes sense in its demands. Good stuff like that.
DLC is cancer but it its nothing compared to CA's current DLC policy so i cant complain much. In fact on a sale you can buy shogun 2, its two expansions and all its DLC for the price of a single DLC of total war warhammer and that says a fucking lot.
I am not even going to mention how many mods you can slap over this badboy to many what is already an great total war game even better, i will leave that up to you to figure out on your own.

A perfectly balanced strategy wargame. Simply put the game does just about everything right. The graphics will not blow you away but they hold up much better than several games younger than this one. The soundtrack is incredible, mellow and frantic in equal measure certain to pull you into your role play of feudal japan. The AI is inconsistent, sometimes hilarious, often times competent and sometimes actually suprisingly resourceful and inventive with it's tactics. A singular criticism that can be filed at this game, albeit a fairly important one, is that the different factions don't play all that different with the differences between them feeling fairly minute especially coming to this from a newer title. All things put aside this remains however one of the best strategy titles of all time. Definitely recommend
